        • AUTODESK
        • ANSYS
    • MEDIA
      • NEWS
      • IMPACT REPORT 24/25
      • SUBSCRIBE
    • CORPORATE
      • PARTNERSHIPS
      • SPONSORSHIPS
      • FRANCHISING
    • CONTACT

0 Comments

We are delighted to announce the continued partnership of Mitutoyo, the world’s leading manufacturer of precision measuring equipment, for the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025. This renewed collaboration reaffirms a shared commitment to excellence, precision, and inspiring the next generation of engineers and innovators.

Mitutoyo’s continued support enhances the event’s technical foundation, playing a crucial role in the scrutineering phase—where each team’s car undergoes a rigorous technical inspection to ensure compliance with strict regulations. Mirroring the exacting standards of a real Formula 1 Grand Prix, scrutineering is conducted under Parc Fermé conditions, with every car examined for precision and accuracy using Mitutoyo’s world-class tools.

Tools such as vernier calipers, digimatic scales, and other advanced metrology instruments will be used by scrutineers to assess each car to millimetre-level accuracy. This level of precision is vital in determining each team’s compliance with technical specifications and maintaining fairness in competition. Teams will also have the unique opportunity to observe this process, gaining firsthand insight into real-world engineering practices.

In the lead-up to the World Finals, participating teams will benefit from exclusive access to the Mitutoyo eLearning platform, a comprehensive digital resource that offers in-depth training on metrology principles, measurement techniques, and tool handling. This access is designed to enhance students’ understanding and skills, supporting their preparation for the crucial scrutineering judging.

Takashi Matsuike, Managing Director of Mitutoyo Asia Pacific, said, “The event has a crucial role in developing the next generation of engineers and innovators; today's training is vital for tomorrow's industry success. The Finals also provide an excellent platform for us to highlight the practical applications of metrology and showcase the essential tools and equipment that drive it.”

Andrew Denford, Founder and CEO of F1 in Schools, adds, “We are proud to have the continued support of Mitutoyo, a global leader in precision engineering. Accurate measurement is at the core of all great engineering—whether it’s a full-scale Formula 1 car or our scale racing models. With Mitutoyo’s tools and expertise, we ensure a level playing field and inspire students to adopt the highest standards of technical excellence.

With a global presence spanning over 100 countries, Mitutoyo offers local support alongside world-class technical expertise. Its comprehensive range of precision measuring solutions—spanning from micrometers, calipers, and indicators to hardness testers, vision measuring systems, form measuring machines, and 3D coordinate measuring machines—makes it the partner of choice for leading industries and educational institutions worldwide.

The continued partnership between Mitutoyo and STEM Racing underscores a mutual dedication to empowering young STEM talent, fostering innovation, and inspiring the engineers of tomorrow through real-world experience, global collaboration, and cutting-edge technology.

Like Post

June 03, 2025

6/3/2025 0 Comments

New strategic partnership with Matrix TSL.

Matrix Technology Solutions and STEM Racing unveil official Wind Tunnel for competitor testing

Matrix Technology Solutions Ltd, Denford Limited and STEM Racing (Formerly F1 in Schools) are excited to announce a strategic partnership focused on enhancing hands-on STEM education. Together, we are proud to unveil the official STEM Racing Wind Tunnel - a state-of-the-art tool designed to help students test, refine, and optimise the aerodynamics of their miniature racing models. This collaboration brings together Matrix’s expertise in engineering education technology with STEM Racing’s dynamic, competition-based learning platform. The result is a powerful educational resource that gives students a deeper understanding of air dynamics, drag, and lift, provided in a classroom-friendly, portable solution.

“This partnership is incredibly exciting for Matrix as our engineering education solutions continue to grow and evolve. From our very first conversation with STEM Racing, it was clear they we had a revolutionary idea - one that would elevate the competition experience for years to come. We’re proud to be part of this journey and to support the next generation of engineers through such an inspiring and impactful programme.” – Liam Walton, Managing Director, Matrix TSL.

The wind tunnel from Matrix, is designed for teaching aerodynamic principles and exploration of fluid flow. Created with an optimally sized testing section to house STEM Racing car models, the wind tunnel enables student teams to gather real-time aerodynamic data to inform their car designs.

“STEM Racing is all about creating engaging experiences that connect theory with real-world application. The introduction of the official STEM Racing Wind Tunnel provides students with a tool that uses state-of-the-art technology to deliver key STEM learning within the STEM Racing programme and elevate their design and engineering process for a competitive edge.

This collaboration with Matrix Technology Solutions provides students with the ability to analyse and test their designs in a controlled environment. We’re not just helping them build faster cars, we’re equipping them with critical thinking, problem-solving, and engineering skills that will benefit both their education and future careers. The wind tunnel is more than just a tool - it’s a launchpad for the next generation of innovators, and we’re excited to see the STEM Racing teams integrating the use of the STEM Racing Wind Tunnel into their F1 car R & D programmes.” - Andrew Denford, Founder and Chairman, STEM Racing Ltd.

The official STEM Racing Wind Tunnel will be available to schools, universities, clubs, and education providers

For more information please click here

May 13th, 2025

5/13/2025 0 Comments

Singapore to host inaugural Aramco STEM Racing World Finals

The highly anticipated Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 is set to take place in Singapore from 27 September to 2 October 2025, running alongside the spectacular Formula 1 Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix 2025.

This landmark event will be the 20th edition of the globally recognized science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) program’s World Finals and the first under its new branding, following the transition from its previous name, F1 in Schools.

Following the success of the Aramco F1 in Schools World Finals 2024 in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia — the headquarters of title partner Aramco — this prestigious event returns to Singapore for the fifth time. Known for its status as a global hub for technology and innovation, Singapore's vibrant cityscape and proven track record of hosting world-class events make it the ideal location for this inaugural event.

The event will bring together the brightest young STEM minds from across the globe. The students have already triumphed in their respective national competitions, earning places at the prestigious World Finals.

With Singapore’s global appeal and the thrill of the Formula 1 night race, the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 is expected to attract a record number of teams. Participants, organized into teams of three to six students, will function as miniature Formula 1 teams, undertaking all aspects of team management. This includes designing, manufacturing, and testing miniature F1 race cars, which they will race on the 20-meter STEM Racing track. Additionally, teams will develop their own team identities, closely mirroring the professional Formula 1 teams competing in the FIA Formula 1 World Championship™

This year’s competition will mark the debut of the Aramco STEM Racing World Champions trophy, to be awarded for the first time to the top-performing team. Alongside this prestigious accolade, teams will compete for over 20 category awards, recognizing achievements across various judging elements, with each award supported by Formula 1 teams and industry suppliers.

Many past competitors have successfully transitioned into careers within Formula 1 and related industries, working in fields such as aerodynamics, engineering, project management, design, finance, and research. The program continues to serve as a premier talent pipeline for the motorsport and engineering sectors. By harnessing the creativity, passion, and technical skills of young minds worldwide, this initiative not only cultivates the next generation of STEM leaders but also inspires them to pursue dynamic careers in the motorsport industry.

Ellen Jones, Formula 1 Head of ESG, said: “Over the past 20 years, STEM Racing has inspired students around the world to pursue careers in engineering. We are proud to support a program that celebrates values that are central to Formula 1 — teamwork, innovation, and problem solving. As F1 celebrates its 75th anniversary, we look to the future, and through competitions like STEM Racing, we hope to find the next generation of talent to push the sport forward. Good luck to all the teams.”

Khalid A. Al Zamil, Aramco Senior Vice President of Corporate Communications, said: “Last year’s Aramco F1 in Schools World Finals, which was held in the Kingdom, showcased how much talent exists in the next generation of engineers. With the STEM Racing team, we aim to equip young pioneers to engineer a brighter future. There is no better way to celebrate our continued partnership than with an exciting world-class finale at the end of September 2025.”

Andrew Denford, STEM Racing Founder and Chairman, said: "The Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 marks an exciting new chapter for our global STEM program. Once again, we will bring together the brightest young STEM talents from around the world to compete at the highest level. The World Champions title is more than just an accolade — it's a gateway to future careers in motorsport, engineering, and beyond."Denford added: “Singapore has always given us a warm welcome, and our students have enjoyed the cultural heritage, the amazing cityscape, and the inspiring setting. The location leaves a lasting impression and gives them all an unforgettable experience, and we can’t wait to be there in September.”With a rich history of innovation and excellence, the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 promises to be a thrilling showcase of young talent, engineering brilliance, and the spirit of competition.

The Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 is supported by title sponsor, Aramco and partners Denford, Autodesk, Ansys, Singapore Grand Prix, Project Management Institute Educational Foundation, UCL Mechanical Engineering, Singapore Tourism Board and FIA Women in Motorsport.

Like Post

December 18th, 2024

12/18/2024 0 Comments

F1 in Schools rebrands to STEM Racing with the continued support of Formula 1

F1 in Schools is rebranding to STEM Racing and will be the latest organisation to be given the ‘supported by Formula 1’ designation. The STEM Racing programme will continue to help thousands of young students around the world in an exciting new era where it will distinguish itself as an independent non-profit organisation, while still harnessing the full support of F1 and the sport’s community.

STEM Racing will continue to drive positive change and inspire the next generation alongside Formula 1, and the core mission of the programme remains to enable students worldwide to pursue STEM subjects in their education with a view to a potential career in motorsport. Through the programme, which is designed for teachers and informed by engineers, ​students aged 6-19 gain insight in areas of STEM through the creation of a miniature F1 car.

Working in small groups, either within classroom learning or in extracurricular activities, students put their own version of an F1 team together where they are assigned roles and responsibilities, such as designing the car, manufacturing it, testing it, branding it, or even becoming the Team Principal to ensure everything runs smoothly. Teams then race against each other and present their cars and wider projects to a panel of judges.

Operating globally, teams showcase their work in regional and national competitions, with the goal of competing in the prestigious World Finals. This year evolut1on, from Germany, were crowned champions at the finals hosted in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. The evolut1on team, and other select students, then had the opportunity to visit the FORMULA 1 QATAR AIRWAYS QATAR GRAND PRIX 2024 at the Lusail International Circuit to get up close and personal with the world of Formula 1. The programme will continue to bring students into the Paddock at Grands Prix around the world, providing hands-on experiences in the world of motorsport and insight from industry personnel.

The support of STEM Racing further enhances the continued efforts by Formula 1 to provide opportunities for young people and those from underrepresented backgrounds to help break down barriers into the motorsport industry by embedding an understanding and excitement for STEM at all levels of education. From school programmes through to scholarships, the Formula 1 community works together to inspire the next generation to pursue their education in our outreach work.

Ellen Jones, Head of ESG, Formula 1 said:


"Education is the cornerstone of the future of F1 and this is why we are so passionate about empowering future generations globally to pursue their dreams in STEM and motorsport. The support for the STEM Racing will build on the fantastic work that has already been done over two decades and is the latest example of how we are continuing to make pathways for young people around the world to achieve their goals and show them what is possible."

Andrew Denford, Founder and Chairman of STEM Racing, commented:


"We're delighted to become an organisation that is officially supported by Formula 1, continuing our mission to bring the excitement of F1 into classrooms worldwide – we aim to inspire future generations to explore STEM and unlock their potential through engaging events and hands-on experiences both on and off the grid.“

Like Post

December 10th, 2024

12/10/2024 0 Comments

26 November 2024: The winners of the Aramco F1 in Schools 2024 World Finals were announced as evolut1on from Karl-Maybach-Gymnasium in Germany. The team of four students, aged 16 – 17 were awarded the prestigious title following a three-day competition against 54 other teams from 25 countries. Becoming the 19th recipients of the title, evolut1on were presented with the accolade by Nabeel A. Al Jama, Executive Vice President, HR and Support Services, Saudi Aramco on stage at a glittering awards ceremony at Dhahran Expo, in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia’s Eastern Province.
Adding to the prestige of the occasion the students were honoured to have two-times Formula 1 World Champion and Aramco Aston Martin Formula One Team driver, Fernando Alonso, attend the Awards ceremony, giving the students an insight into his career in a Q & A session and meeting many of the teams in a tour of the Pit Displays. He then kicked-o the final races of the Knockout Competition and presented the Aston Martin Aramco Formula One Team supported “Best Newcomer Award” to the winners, Agilas, from the Philippines.

10 lucky students celebrated winning a coveted place in the Komatsu-Williams Engineering Academy, a global initiative designed to cultivate the next generation of engineering talent. The Academy’s first intake have been selected exclusively from this year’s World Finals students. By joining the Academy, students will gain invaluable experience and insights, benefiting from the combined expertise and resources of both Komatsu and Williams Racing. ​

The Aramco F1 in Schools World Champions title is highly recognized within the engineering and motorsport industries due to its rigorous judging criteria. Encompassing design, engineering, project management, innovation, marketing, and presentation skills, the multi-disciplinary challenge requires students to demonstrate a high level of competence and expertise across a range of subject areas. Many members of past teams who have secured the World Champions title have progressed to roles within F1 teams, including Lewis Fowler and George Stonor of 2019 winners, Evolve UK; Kyriakos Theofanidis of 2016 winners, Infinite Racing; and George and Max Britton of 2015 winners, Union Racing International, among others.

​With the award determined by scoring from a panel of over 60 industry judges, comprised of professionals from a range of industries, including STEM, marketing, motorsport, and education, the team achieved the highest scores across the board, and received particular recognition for their performance in engineering becoming the recipients of the Research and Development award, sponsored by McLaren.

Commenting on their achievement, Team Manager, Theo Paulsen, 16, said: “We really didn’t believe we would win. We’ve spent over two years working on this and put thousands of hours into it, it’s just amazing to have beaten all these other talented teams. We’re in shock at the moment, we just can’t quite believe it, I think it will take a while to sink in. The experience has been so special and the hospitality in Saudi Arabia has been wonderful.”

This year’s Aramco F1 in Schools World Finals was the first time the event has taken place in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and has seen over 450 students and educators from 25 countries visit the Kingdom to compete. O icially welcomed by the Cultural Partner, Ithra, on Saturday, students visited the famous center to gain insight into Saudi Arabian culture before the next day’s competition. The event will conclude with students visiting Qatar ahead of the Formula 1 Qatar Airways Qatar Grand Prix, for an exclusive pit lane walk at Lusail International Circuit on Thursday

Khalid Al-Zamil, Aramco Vice President of Public A airs, said: “This year’s Aramco F1 in Schools World Finals showcased just how much talent exists within this next generation of engineers and pioneers. Evolut1on did a phenomenal job to achieve the World Champions title. Having the event take place within our home country has made the event particularly special for Aramco as an organization, and it has been an honor and a delight to share our culture with these incredible young people.”

​Andrew Denford, Founder and Chairman of F1 in Schools, said: “evolut1on truly shone throughout the competition, and we are proud to announce that they are our new World Champions. The standard on show was incredibly high this year, so to beat 54 teams to the title is just a brilliant achievement, and we can’t wait to see what they go on to do next.” ​

REGISTER

How to Compete in STEM Racing

Ready to join the STEM Racing challenge? Here’s how you can get started:

  1. Check the Rules & Regulations

    The official Rules & Regulations will soon be available in the Country List section and on local websites. These guidelines are essential for ensuring your team meets all competition requirements and stays on track for success.

  2. Connect with Your Local Coordinator

    Use the Country List to find your national coordinator’s contact information. They’ll provide details on how to register and help you navigate the competition process in your region.

    3. Stay tuned for updates, and prepare to embark on your STEM Racing journey. The race to innovation starts here!

© COPYRIGHT ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

COOKIES POLICY

Information about our use of cookies

Our website uses cookies to distinguish you from other users of our website. This helps us to provide you with a good experience when you browse our website and also allows us to improve our site. By continuing to browse the site, you are agreeing to our use of cookies and our Cookie Policy in the entirety

A cookies is a small file of letters and numbers that we store on your browser or the hard drive of your computer if your agree. Cookies contain information that is transferred to your computer's hard drive

We use analytical/performance cookies whichallows us to recognise and count the number of visitors and see how visitors move around our website when they are using it. This helps us to improve the way our website works, for example, by ensuring that users are finding whgat they are looking for easily

You can find more information about the individual cookies we use and the purposes for which we use them in the tables below

  • www.stemracing.com
  • www.stemracing.co.uk

This site uses the following cookies:

    • Name-Is_mobile
    • Duration - This expires when you close your browser
    • Information - It allows you to view the website in full site and mobile site modes
    • Name - language
    • Duration - This expires after 14 days
    • Information - It is used to store the language used by the website

Please note that third parties (including, for example,advertising networks and providers of external serviecs like web traffic analysis services) may also use cookies, over which we have no control. These cookies are likely to be analytical/performance cookies or targeting cookies although we cannot confirm this

You can block cookies by activating the setting on browser that allows you to refuse the setting of all or some cookies. However, if you use your browser settings to block all cookies (including essential cookies) you may not be able to access all or parts of our site

In accordance with data protection legislation, we will not store your cookies for any longer than we believe is necessary.

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

    • CONTACT

DEVELOPMENT CLASS -11 TO 19

The next step in the competition, Development Class builds on everything students have learned in Entry Class, introducing new requirements to aid learning

WHATS INVOLVED

Teams once again begin with the STEM Racing Entry/Development Class Starter Kit, however with the ability to design more complex wings, cars begin to evidence advanced consideration of aerodynamics.

DESIGN: The use of Autodesk CAD software becomes technically advanced, with regulations that require students to create innovative wings, and chassis which feature a new ‘no go’ area.

ANALYSE: Ansys CFD software can now be used by teams to illustrate that they have used data to optimise their design, making modifications based on virtual performance.

MAKE: At this stage, it becomes mandatory to CNC machine the car body, wings can sill be created using 3D printing. Hand carving is no longer allowed.

TEST: Ansys CFD software can once again be used to perform virtual tests.

RACE: Cars are raced on a 20-metre elevated racetrack, powered by 8 gram cannisters of compressed air.

PROJECT MANAGEMENNT: Teams demonstrate how they have put principles into practice.

THE REQUIREMENTS

When competing in an STEM RACING event, teams will be assessed on:

DESIGN & ENGINEERING PORTFOLIO: A five-page document discussing a range of topics, including use of CAM/CNC technologies.

VERBAL PRESENTATION: Lasting five minutes, teams will be assessed on technique, composition, and content.

BRAND IDENTITY: Teams create a pit display marked on a number of criteria, including sustainability.

SCRUTINEERING: Teams are assessed on renderings, alongside their physical cars.

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

STEM RACING
GLOBAL ENROLMENT

Before registering for a regional final in your country, you will need to obtain an enrolment code from STEM Racing Ltd. ​ Once you have filled out this form you will be sent your enrolment code which you can then use to register for your in country competition.

STEM Racing™ Global Enrolment

Before registering for a regional final in your country, you will need to obtain an enrolment code from STEM Racing Ltd. Once you have filled out this form you will be sent your enrolment code which you can then use to register for your in country competition.

TEAM Details

If your team name is not yet confirmed please state 'unknown' in box below

Software & Equipment

For each of the following stages of the design process please state which CAD/CAM software has been or will be used at each stage.

Under the following headings please give the name of the relevant piece of equipment you have used / will be using to manufacture your car.

If this information is not yet known please state 'unknown' in box below. If this information is not yet known please state 'unknown' in box below.

Please tick this box if you would NOT like to receive updates via email from STEM Racing Ltd.

By entering your information into this form you consent to STEM Racing Ltd. forwarding your details to the authorised F1 in Schools co-ordinator in your country and will be used solely for the purpose of facilitating the challenge.

Send me a copy of my responses

Privacy Policy | Report Abuse

This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

ENTRY CLASS -9 TO 11

The ideal starting point for students hoping to progress through the classes of the competition, Entry Class provides the perfect learning foundation.

WHATS INVOLVED

To get started, purchase an STEM Racing Entry/Development Class Starter Kit, available individually or in packs of five. This contains wheels, axles, and model blocks.

DESIGN: Providing a brilliant introduction to basic CAD skills, teams can use the intuitive Autodesk Fusion 360 - provided free to all students - to design their car’s body and wings.

ANALYSE: Introducing CFD software, students receive free access to Ansys products and learning resources, which enable them to explore the use of data analysis for design optimisation.

MAKE: With three manufacturing options allowed, teams can choose to hand carve, 3D print, or CNC machine their car body!

TEST: Virtual tests can be ran using Ansys CFD software, assessing the impact of different air flows, and more. But the best test is on the track!

RACE: At competition, cars are raced on a 20-metre elevated racetrack, powered by 8 gram cannisters of compressed air.

PROJECT MANAGEMENNT: A guide is provided to all students for independent learning.

THE REQUIREMENTS

When competing in an STEM RACING event, teams will be assessed on:

DESIGN & ENGINEERING PORTFOLIO: A five-page document which discusses a number of elements, including initial ideas and inclusion of 3D sketches.

VERBAL PRESENTATION: Lasting five minutes, this should include a number of key areas, including learning experiences and evidence of collaboration.

SCRUTINEERING: The technical regulations provide students with a range of challenges relating to dimensions, weight, size, and compliance with a ‘no go’ area.

RESEARCH MISSION: At the event, teams are given a challenge which encourages research and reflection.

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

EQUIPMENTS

STEM Racing is developed to be inclusive and accessible to students, teachers, and schools of all means and experience levels.

As a result, each class has a detailed Competition Guidebook which contains all the information needed to get started – from how to create a pit display to the details a team’s engineering portfolio should include to wow the judges. Alongside this guidebook, access to CAD, CFD, and CAM software is provided free of charge, with an array of learning resources also available to guide teams from concept to completion. An engaged network of STEM RACING Centres of Excellence is present across the globe, and these sites are home to the manufacturing equipment needed to make teams’ cars, if a school does not have them in the classroom.

starter packs

These are available to purchase from Denford, the official equipment supplier of STEM RACING, and other authorised resellers across the globe.

cad software

The Premier Global CAD/CAM Partner of STEM RACING, Autodesk provides all participants with free access to a fantastic range of software and learning resources.

cfd software

The Premier Global CFD Partner of STEM RACING, Ansys provides all participants with free access to their student software package and learning resources.

cnc machines

Denford offers an extensive selection of CNC machines, with an option for every budget, although other brands can be used for entry in the competition

race equipment

To create the race day experience in the classroom, racetracks, start gates, and deceleration systems can all be purchased from Denford Ltd.

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

Contact Us

* INDICATES REQUIRED FIELD

I agree to receive marketing and promotional materials from STEM RACINNG.

Frederique Trouve

    • CONTACT

franchising

Become a STEM Racing Local Representative

Are you passionate about STEM education and ready to inspire the next generation of innovators? STEM Racing is expanding globally, and we’re looking for motivated individuals and organizations to join us as local representatives through our franchising program.
As a local representative, you will:

  • Bring STEM Racing to Your Community: Organize competitions and foster a culture of innovation and learning in your region.
  • Empower Future Leaders: Help students develop critical skills in engineering, teamwork, and problem-solving.
  • Access Comprehensive Support: Benefit from training, resources, and guidance to ensure the success of the program in your country.

This is your opportunity to be part of a global movement shaping the future of STEM education. If you’re ready to take the lead and grow the challenge in your region, we’d love to hear from you!

​Get in touch today to start your journey as a STEM Racing representative!

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

    • CONTACT

Teachers, it's your turn to learn!

We’re thrilled to partner with Autodesk to bring you a series of FREE CPD courses designed to equip you with the skills and confidence to teach Computer Aided Design (CAD) and Computer Aided Manufacturing (CAM) using Autodesk Fusion. Developed specifically for STEM Racing, over the coming months, these hands-on, entry-level courses will empower you to bring STEM learning to life by enabling your students to design and manufacture their own STEM Racing cars — all from your classroom.

Fully funded and available at no cost to your or your school, make sure you don't miss out and book your place today.

cad fusion fundamentals

Time required: 12-hour course which runs over one full and one half day.

In easy-to-follow, live online sessions, you’ll explore the essential tools in Autodesk Fusion and gain the tools and confidence to guide your students through the car design process, from sketch to final render.

Key Learnings:

  • How to navigate the Fusion interface
  • ​2D sketching fundamentals
  • 3D modelling techniques: Extrude, Loft, Mirror
  • Building and managing assemblies
  • Creating detailed technical drawings
  • Rendering your car designs
  • Maximising Fusion’s features for speed, performance and creativity

CAM FUSION FUNDAMENTALS

​Time required? 8-hour course taking place over one full day or two after-school sessions.

In this engaging, instructor-led course, you’ll gain the skills to bring real-world manufacturing into your classroom and help your students build faster, smarter, and more competitive cars.

Key Learnings:

  • How to set up Fusion CAM and pair it with a CNC machine
  • Creating 2.5, 3, and 4-axis toolpaths
  • Simulating machining and generating G-code
  • Using Fusion effectively, even without a CNC machine
  • Tips to prep students for the Fusion ACU exam and technical judging

NEED A DIFFERENT DATE?

If you'd like to complete this free training but are unable to make any of the dates listed, you can attend a general Autodesk Fusion Fundamentals course at the links below. ​

Alternatively, if you'd like to receive a custom STEM Racing + Autodesk session, get in touch with the team today and let us know what date/s would for you and we will try our best to accommodate a new course.

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

your pathway to a career in f1

EXCLUSIVE OPPORTUNITY FOR STEM RACING 2025 WORLD FINALISTS ​TO JOIN THE KOMATSU-WILLIAMS RACING ENGINEERING ACADEMY

We are delighted to once again partner with Komatsu-Williams Racing Engineering Academy the STEM Racing World Finals. Providing our World Finalists with a highly prized opportunity to join the academy as part of the 2026 cohort, this partnership offers students the chance to get to the heart of innovation in Formula 1.

So, if you want to experience engineering at its highest level, build connections in one of the world's most competitive industries, and learn from some of the best minds in the business, submit your application now (your exclusive application link has been sent to your email address; if you haven't received it, contact the STEM Racing team).

Applications close at midnight, August 15th 2025.

Please note, there is no cost associated with being part of the academy, this is a purely merit-based opportunity.

WHY APPLY

The academy is looking for the brightest and best, curious engineers who want to build, break and push boundaries. It’s a one-of-a-kind opportunity that combines hands-on engineering experience with personalised mentorship and exclusive industry exposure.

As an academy member, you'll receive:

  • Access to e-learning educational F1 modules and tasks
  • Engagement with your own mentor from Komatsu or Williams Racing
  • Early access to career opportunities
  • Many other cross company initiatives
  • The ability to build global networks; learning and connecting with the community.​​

HOW DO i APPLY?

The application process will consist of 2 stages:

Stage 1 -Submit your CV, cover letter and video via the link sent to your email address by STEM Racing HQ.

Applications will close at midnight on: Friday 15th August 2025

Stage 2 - Successful individuals will be invited to attend our Assessment Centre at the World Finals in Singapore.

Please note you must be present in Singapore and able to attend the assessment centre to be eligible to apply. The assessment centre will take place on Wednesday 1st October.

FAQS

The programme begins in January 2026.

How long is the academy?

This will depend upon your year of study and your home country. Our learning platform provides engineering insight over the course of three years.

Are students able to attend a race weekend?

Attending grand prix races is not guaranteed. Last year, academy members joined Atlassian Williams Racing in Qatar. Details of the schedule in Singapore will be released shortly.

passion to pitlane

"This is one of the best early careers opportunities in F1, if not the best. The chance to grow with the team is something that will be invaluable in the future.

​My biggest advice? Be yourself at the assessment centre. The team wants to see how you think, solve problems, and collaborate.

​Step up to lead when the moment’s right, listen to others, and show your strengths honestly. Come in with confidence and a positive mindset, and make sure they see why you’re the best choice for the academy."

Aran, Aeros Racing, 2025 World Finalist and Komatsu-Williams Racing Engineering Academy member

If you have any further questions, please reach out to the academy at Earlycareers@williamsf1.com.

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

    • CONTACT

REGISTER

Introducing the STEM Racing Learning Channel!

Starting early 2025, STEM Racing will launch an innovative Learning Channel designed to support students every step of the way in their competition journey. This platform will offer a rich collection of resources, including video tutorials, guides, expert tips, and interactive tools, tailored to help you master key skills in engineering, design, project management, and teamwork. Whether you're just starting or preparing for the finals, the Learning Channel will be your ultimate companion in the race for success.


Get ready to elevate your performance and power up your knowledge. Stay tuned for the launch and take your STEM Racing journey to the next level!

© COPYRIGHT ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

        • CONTACT (SA)
      • SPAIN
        • CONTACT (SP)
      • SWITZERLAND
        • CONTACT (SIW)
      • SAUDI ARABIA

    • CONTACT

AMARON POWERS UP AS PREMIUM PARTNER OF ARAMCO STEM RACING WORLD FINALS 2025

9/19/2025 0 Comments

Amaron, Flagship brand of India’s leading automotive battery manufacturer, will energise the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 as a Premium Partner, supporting the world’s largest global student STEM competition taking place from 27 September to 2 October at Resorts World Sentosa, Singapore.

As part of this partnership, Amaron will sponsor the third-place podium award and present the official 3rd Place Trophy to one of the world’s top STEM Racing teams. Formerly known as F1 in Schools, the programme rebranded to STEM Racing earlier this year and is set to host its largest World Finals to date, with more than 80 student teams competing from around the globe.

For Amaron, this partnership is about powering the future. By backing a platform that pushes students to design, innovate, and engineer under pressure, Amaron is reaffirming its belief in the young generation as drivers of superior technology and changemakers of tomorrow. The brand sees clear synergies between its ethos of endurance, performance, and reliability and the qualities that STEM Racing instils in participants worldwide.

Harshavardhana Gourineni, Executive Director, Amara Raja Energy & Mobility said “We believe the future belongs to young innovators who dare to think differently and build superior technologies for a better tomorrow. This partnership with STEM Racing fits seamlessly with Amaron’s ethos of supporting future generations of innovators and encouraging them to push the boundaries of engineering. The STEM Racing programme challenges young people to design with precision, think creatively, and work as a team to achieve results under pressure and we are truly delighted to join the roster of STEM Racing partners for such a prestigious event and to play our part in energising the largest World Finals to date”

Andrew Denford, Founder and Chairman, STEM Racing, added: “Our mission has always been to ignite a passion for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics by giving students the chance to experience innovation in action. Partners like Amaron make it possible for us to deliver a truly world-class competition, where young people from every corner of the globe can test their skills and showcase their creativity. Having Amaron on board, with their reputation for cutting-edge technology and long-lasting performance, sends a powerful message to our students: that industry leaders believe in their talent and want to invest in their future. We’re thrilled to have them as part of the STEM Racing family.”

The collaboration, resilience, and innovation that these students demonstrate are the same qualities that drive progress in the workplace and the wider world. At Amaron, we believe these qualities deserve to be celebrated, and we are proud to stand alongside STEM Racing in applauding and empowering the changemakers of tomorrow.”

As Premium Partner of the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025, Amaron reinforces its focus on nurturing the next generation of innovators. In addition to its global partnership, the brand is also extending its support to a team from India competing at the event.

Like Post

New era for aramco stem racing world finals

9/3/2025 0 Comments

The countdown has begun for the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025, and a bold new chapter for the world’s most prestigious STEM education competition. Reimagined and rebranded from the globally recognised F1 in Schools, this year’s event will not only celebrate a rich 20-year legacy—it will also crown the very first Aramco STEM Racing World Champions.

From 27 September to 2 October, the global spotlight will shine on Sentosa Island, Singapore, as over 80 student teams from across more than 30 nations gather to compete at the cutting edge of creativity, engineering, and enterprise. From designing and engineering the fastest miniature Formula 1-inspired race car to showcasing excellence in marketing, teamwork, and project management, these student teams will be vying for the World Champions crown. And this year, the World Finals are shifting into an even higher gear.

For the first time ever, the World Finals will feature four-lane racing, a spectacular evolution from the traditional head-to-head duels of past Finals. Now, four teams will line up side-by-side, their miniature race cars primed for a simultaneous launch that promises twice the adrenaline and four times the spectacle.

This game-changing innovation introduces new technical and mental challenges, especially for the drivers who must stay laser-focused on a single set of lights while flanked by three rival competitors. Nerves of steel and split-second timing will be tested like never before.

In another landmark moment, this will be the largest STEM Racing World Finals in history, with more than 80 teams qualifying through rigorous national competitions. Included in the 33 countries competing will be first-time contenders from Costa Rica, having recently introduced STEM Racing to schools in the country.

Technical regulation changes include a reduction in minimum car weight and the introduction of legal ballast, and minor adjustments to the Formula 1 model car dimensions.

Andrew Denford, Founder and Chairman, STEM Racing, says, “Every year, I say the World Finals will be the biggest and best yet and every year, the teams prove me right. But 2025 truly marks a transformative moment for STEM Racing. With the debut of our custom-designed four-lane track, we’re adding an entirely new layer of excitement and complexity to the competition. It’s a visual and technical spectacle, made possible by the incredible scale of this year’s event, with over 90 teams competing from around the globe.

“Welcoming new countries like Costa Rica to the Finals is always one of the most rewarding parts of our work. Expanding our global reach means more students from diverse backgrounds can experience this life-changing journey—building friendships across borders, sharing cultures, and connecting through a shared passion for STEM.”

The Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 is proudly supported by title sponsor, Aramco and key partners including Denford, Autodesk, Ansys, Singapore Grand Prix, DHL, Project Management Institute Educational Foundation, Mitutoyo, UCL Mechanical Engineering, Singapore Tourism Board and the FIA.

Like Post

0 Comments

We are delighted to announce the continued partnership of Mitutoyo, the world’s leading manufacturer of precision measuring equipment, for the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025. This renewed collaboration reaffirms a shared commitment to excellence, precision, and inspiring the next generation of engineers and innovators.

Mitutoyo’s continued support enhances the event’s technical foundation, playing a crucial role in the scrutineering phase—where each team’s car undergoes a rigorous technical inspection to ensure compliance with strict regulations. Mirroring the exacting standards of a real Formula 1 Grand Prix, scrutineering is conducted under Parc Fermé conditions, with every car examined for precision and accuracy using Mitutoyo’s world-class tools.

Tools such as vernier calipers, digimatic scales, and other advanced metrology instruments will be used by scrutineers to assess each car to millimetre-level accuracy. This level of precision is vital in determining each team’s compliance with technical specifications and maintaining fairness in competition. Teams will also have the unique opportunity to observe this process, gaining firsthand insight into real-world engineering practices.

In the lead-up to the World Finals, participating teams will benefit from exclusive access to the Mitutoyo eLearning platform, a comprehensive digital resource that offers in-depth training on metrology principles, measurement techniques, and tool handling. This access is designed to enhance students’ understanding and skills, supporting their preparation for the crucial scrutineering judging.

Takashi Matsuike, Managing Director of Mitutoyo Asia Pacific, said, “The event has a crucial role in developing the next generation of engineers and innovators; today's training is vital for tomorrow's industry success. The Finals also provide an excellent platform for us to highlight the practical applications of metrology and showcase the essential tools and equipment that drive it.”

Andrew Denford, Founder and CEO of F1 in Schools, adds, “We are proud to have the continued support of Mitutoyo, a global leader in precision engineering. Accurate measurement is at the core of all great engineering—whether it’s a full-scale Formula 1 car or our scale racing models. With Mitutoyo’s tools and expertise, we ensure a level playing field and inspire students to adopt the highest standards of technical excellence.

With a global presence spanning over 100 countries, Mitutoyo offers local support alongside world-class technical expertise. Its comprehensive range of precision measuring solutions—spanning from micrometers, calipers, and indicators to hardness testers, vision measuring systems, form measuring machines, and 3D coordinate measuring machines—makes it the partner of choice for leading industries and educational institutions worldwide.

The continued partnership between Mitutoyo and STEM Racing underscores a mutual dedication to empowering young STEM talent, fostering innovation, and inspiring the engineers of tomorrow through real-world experience, global collaboration, and cutting-edge technology.

Like Post

June 03rd, 2025

6/3/2025 0 comments

New strategic partnership with Matrix TSL.

Matrix Technology Solutions and STEM Racing unveil official Wind Tunnel for competitor testing

Matrix Technology Solutions Ltd, Denford Limited and STEM Racing (Formerly F1 in Schools) are excited to announce a strategic partnership focused on enhancing hands-on STEM education. Together, we are proud to unveil the official STEM Racing Wind Tunnel - a state-of-the-art tool designed to help students test, refine, and optimise the aerodynamics of their miniature racing models. This collaboration brings together Matrix’s expertise in engineering education technology with STEM Racing’s dynamic, competition-based learning platform. The result is a powerful educational resource that gives students a deeper understanding of air dynamics, drag, and lift, provided in a classroom-friendly, portable solution.

“This partnership is incredibly exciting for Matrix as our engineering education solutions continue to grow and evolve. From our very first conversation with STEM Racing, it was clear they we had a revolutionary idea - one that would elevate the competition experience for years to come. We’re proud to be part of this journey and to support the next generation of engineers through such an inspiring and impactful programme.” – Liam Walton, Managing Director, Matrix TSL.

The wind tunnel from Matrix, is designed for teaching aerodynamic principles and exploration of fluid flow. Created with an optimally sized testing section to house STEM Racing car models, the wind tunnel enables student teams to gather real-time aerodynamic data to inform their car designs.

“STEM Racing is all about creating engaging experiences that connect theory with real-world application. The introduction of the official STEM Racing Wind Tunnel provides students with a tool that uses state-of-the-art technology to deliver key STEM learning within the STEM Racing programme and elevate their design and engineering process for a competitive edge.

This collaboration with Matrix Technology Solutions provides students with the ability to analyse and test their designs in a controlled environment. We’re not just helping them build faster cars, we’re equipping them with critical thinking, problem-solving, and engineering skills that will benefit both their education and future careers. The wind tunnel is more than just a tool - it’s a launchpad for the next generation of innovators, and we’re excited to see the STEM Racing teams integrating the use of the STEM Racing Wind Tunnel into their F1 car R & D programmes.” - Andrew Denford, Founder and Chairman, STEM Racing Ltd.

The official STEM Racing Wind Tunnel will be available to schools, universities, clubs, and education providers

For more information please click here

Like Post

May 13th, 2025

5/13/2025 0 Comments

Singapore to host inaugural Aramco STEM Racing World Finals

The highly anticipated Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 is set to take place in Singapore from 27 September to 2 October 2025, running alongside the spectacular Formula 1 Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix 2025.

This landmark event will be the 20th edition of the globally recognized science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) program’s World Finals and the first under its new branding, following the transition from its previous name, F1 in Schools.

Following the success of the Aramco F1 in Schools World Finals 2024 in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia — the headquarters of title partner Aramco — this prestigious event returns to Singapore for the fifth time. Known for its status as a global hub for technology and innovation, Singapore's vibrant cityscape and proven track record of hosting world-class events make it the ideal location for this inaugural event.

The event will bring together the brightest young STEM minds from across the globe. The students have already triumphed in their respective national competitions, earning places at the prestigious World Finals.

With Singapore’s global appeal and the thrill of the Formula 1 night race, the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 is expected to attract a record number of teams. Participants, organized into teams of three to six students, will function as miniature Formula 1 teams, undertaking all aspects of team management. This includes designing, manufacturing, and testing miniature F1 race cars, which they will race on the 20-meter STEM Racing track. Additionally, teams will develop their own team identities, closely mirroring the professional Formula 1 teams competing in the FIA Formula 1 World Championship™

This year’s competition will mark the debut of the Aramco STEM Racing World Champions trophy, to be awarded for the first time to the top-performing team. Alongside this prestigious accolade, teams will compete for over 20 category awards, recognizing achievements across various judging elements, with each award supported by Formula 1 teams and industry suppliers.

Many past competitors have successfully transitioned into careers within Formula 1 and related industries, working in fields such as aerodynamics, engineering, project management, design, finance, and research. The program continues to serve as a premier talent pipeline for the motorsport and engineering sectors. By harnessing the creativity, passion, and technical skills of young minds worldwide, this initiative not only cultivates the next generation of STEM leaders but also inspires them to pursue dynamic careers in the motorsport industry.

Ellen Jones, Formula 1 Head of ESG, said: “Over the past 20 years, STEM Racing has inspired students around the world to pursue careers in engineering. We are proud to support a program that celebrates values that are central to Formula 1 — teamwork, innovation, and problem solving. As F1 celebrates its 75th anniversary, we look to the future, and through competitions like STEM Racing, we hope to find the next generation of talent to push the sport forward. Good luck to all the teams.”

Khalid A. Al Zamil, Aramco Senior Vice President of Corporate Communications, said: “Last year’s Aramco F1 in Schools World Finals, which was held in the Kingdom, showcased how much talent exists in the next generation of engineers. With the STEM Racing team, we aim to equip young pioneers to engineer a brighter future. There is no better way to celebrate our continued partnership than with an exciting world-class finale at the end of September 2025.”

Andrew Denford, STEM Racing Founder and Chairman, said: "The Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 marks an exciting new chapter for our global STEM program. Once again, we will bring together the brightest young STEM talents from around the world to compete at the highest level. The World Champions title is more than just an accolade — it's a gateway to future careers in motorsport, engineering, and beyond."Denford added: “Singapore has always given us a warm welcome, and our students have enjoyed the cultural heritage, the amazing cityscape, and the inspiring setting. The location leaves a lasting impression and gives them all an unforgettable experience, and we can’t wait to be there in September.”With a rich history of innovation and excellence, the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 promises to be a thrilling showcase of young talent, engineering brilliance, and the spirit of competition.

The Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025 is supported by title sponsor, Aramco and partners Denford, Autodesk, Ansys, Singapore Grand Prix, Project Management Institute Educational Foundation, UCL Mechanical Engineering, Singapore Tourism Board and FIA Women in Motorsport.

Like Post

December 18th, 2024

12/18/2024 0 Comments

F1 in Schools rebrands to STEM Racing with the continued support of Formula 1

F1 in Schools is rebranding to STEM Racing and will be the latest organisation to be given the ‘supported by Formula 1’ designation. The STEM Racing programme will continue to help thousands of young students around the world in an exciting new era where it will distinguish itself as an independent non-profit organisation, while still harnessing the full support of F1 and the sport’s community.

STEM Racing will continue to drive positive change and inspire the next generation alongside Formula 1, and the core mission of the programme remains to enable students worldwide to pursue STEM subjects in their education with a view to a potential career in motorsport. Through the programme, which is designed for teachers and informed by engineers, ​students aged 6-19 gain insight in areas of STEM through the creation of a miniature F1 car.

Working in small groups, either within classroom learning or in extracurricular activities, students put their own version of an F1 team together where they are assigned roles and responsibilities, such as designing the car, manufacturing it, testing it, branding it, or even becoming the Team Principal to ensure everything runs smoothly. Teams then race against each other and present their cars and wider projects to a panel of judges.

Operating globally, teams showcase their work in regional and national competitions, with the goal of competing in the prestigious World Finals. This year evolut1on, from Germany, were crowned champions at the finals hosted in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. The evolut1on team, and other select students, then had the opportunity to visit the FORMULA 1 QATAR AIRWAYS QATAR GRAND PRIX 2024 at the Lusail International Circuit to get up close and personal with the world of Formula 1. The programme will continue to bring students into the Paddock at Grands Prix around the world, providing hands-on experiences in the world of motorsport and insight from industry personnel.

The support of STEM Racing further enhances the continued efforts by Formula 1 to provide opportunities for young people and those from underrepresented backgrounds to help break down barriers into the motorsport industry by embedding an understanding and excitement for STEM at all levels of education. From school programmes through to scholarships, the Formula 1 community works together to inspire the next generation to pursue their education in our outreach work.

Ellen Jones, Head of ESG, Formula 1 said:


"Education is the cornerstone of the future of F1 and this is why we are so passionate about empowering future generations globally to pursue their dreams in STEM and motorsport. The support for the STEM Racing will build on the fantastic work that has already been done over two decades and is the latest example of how we are continuing to make pathways for young people around the world to achieve their goals and show them what is possible."

Andrew Denford, Founder and Chairman of STEM Racing, commented:


"We're delighted to become an organisation that is officially supported by Formula 1, continuing our mission to bring the excitement of F1 into classrooms worldwide – we aim to inspire future generations to explore STEM and unlock their potential through engaging events and hands-on experiences both on and off the grid.“

Like Post

December 10th, 2024

12/10/2024 0 comments

26 November 2024: The winners of the Aramco F1 in Schools 2024 World Finals were announced as evolut1on from Karl-Maybach-Gymnasium in Germany. The team of four students, aged 16 – 17 were awarded the prestigious title following a three-day competition against 54 other teams from 25 countries. Becoming the 19th recipients of the title, evolut1on were presented with the accolade by Nabeel A. Al Jama, Executive Vice President, HR and Support Services, Saudi Aramco on stage at a glittering awards ceremony at Dhahran Expo, in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia’s Eastern Province.
Adding to the prestige of the occasion the students were honoured to have two-times Formula 1 World Champion and Aramco Aston Martin Formula One Team driver, Fernando Alonso, attend the Awards ceremony, giving the students an insight into his career in a Q & A session and meeting many of the teams in a tour of the Pit Displays. He then kicked-o the final races of the Knockout Competition and presented the Aston Martin Aramco Formula One Team supported “Best Newcomer Award” to the winners, Agilas, from the Philippines.

10 lucky students celebrated winning a coveted place in the Komatsu-Williams Engineering Academy, a global initiative designed to cultivate the next generation of engineering talent. The Academy’s first intake have been selected exclusively from this year’s World Finals students. By joining the Academy, students will gain invaluable experience and insights, benefiting from the combined expertise and resources of both Komatsu and Williams Racing. ​

The Aramco F1 in Schools World Champions title is highly recognized within the engineering and motorsport industries due to its rigorous judging criteria. Encompassing design, engineering, project management, innovation, marketing, and presentation skills, the multi-disciplinary challenge requires students to demonstrate a high level of competence and expertise across a range of subject areas. Many members of past teams who have secured the World Champions title have progressed to roles within F1 teams, including Lewis Fowler and George Stonor of 2019 winners, Evolve UK; Kyriakos Theofanidis of 2016 winners, Infinite Racing; and George and Max Britton of 2015 winners, Union Racing International, among others.

​With the award determined by scoring from a panel of over 60 industry judges, comprised of professionals from a range of industries, including STEM, marketing, motorsport, and education, the team achieved the highest scores across the board, and received particular recognition for their performance in engineering becoming the recipients of the Research and Development award, sponsored by McLaren.

Commenting on their achievement, Team Manager, Theo Paulsen, 16, said: “We really didn’t believe we would win. We’ve spent over two years working on this and put thousands of hours into it, it’s just amazing to have beaten all these other talented teams. We’re in shock at the moment, we just can’t quite believe it, I think it will take a while to sink in. The experience has been so special and the hospitality in Saudi Arabia has been wonderful.”

This year’s Aramco F1 in Schools World Finals was the first time the event has taken place in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and has seen over 450 students and educators from 25 countries visit the Kingdom to compete. O icially welcomed by the Cultural Partner, Ithra, on Saturday, students visited the famous center to gain insight into Saudi Arabian culture before the next day’s competition. The event will conclude with students visiting Qatar ahead of the Formula 1 Qatar Airways Qatar Grand Prix, for an exclusive pit lane walk at Lusail International Circuit on Thursday

Khalid Al-Zamil, Aramco Vice President of Public A airs, said: “This year’s Aramco F1 in Schools World Finals showcased just how much talent exists within this next generation of engineers and pioneers. Evolut1on did a phenomenal job to achieve the World Champions title. Having the event take place within our home country has made the event particularly special for Aramco as an organization, and it has been an honor and a delight to share our culture with these incredible young people.”

​Andrew Denford, Founder and Chairman of F1 in Schools, said: “evolut1on truly shone throughout the competition, and we are proud to announce that they are our new World Champions. The standard on show was incredibly high this year, so to beat 54 teams to the title is just a brilliant achievement, and we can’t wait to see what they go on to do next.” ​

partnerships

Collaborate with STEM Racing and Uncover Global Talent

At STEM Racing, our mission is to discover and nurture the brightest minds in STEM, and we believe that collaboration is key to reaching that goal. If your organization shares our vision of empowering the next generation of innovators, we invite you to join us as a collaborative partner.
A great example of this kind of collaboration is our partnership with the Williams Academy, who have worked with us to help develop and inspire young talent in engineering and design. Their commitment to identifying and mentoring future leaders in STEM has been invaluable, and we’re excited to continue working with organizations like Williams to expand the reach of STEM Racing globally.
By collaborating with STEM Racing, you can:

  • Support Talent Discovery: Help identify and develop the next generation of leaders in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.
  • Contribute to Global Impact: Partner with us to create opportunities for students worldwide to showcase their skills and unlock their potential.
  • Align with a Shared Vision: Be part of a movement that encourages creativity, teamwork, and innovation across borders.

We’re seeking like-minded organizations to join us in expanding the STEM Racing challenge and reaching even more talented students worldwide. Together, we can make a lasting impact on the future of STEM.

Join us in discovering talent around the world and shaping tomorrow’s innovators. Reach out today to learn how we can collaborate!

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

      • FRANCHISING
    • CONTACT

PRIMARY CLASS -9 TO 11

Igniting the spark of innovation at a young age, F1 in Schools Primary Class introduces pupils to the different elements of the competition in an accessible way.

WHATS INVOLVED

To get started, a school purchases an STEM Racing Primary Class Starter Pack. This contains everything a class of up to 50 students needs to begin including perforated card to make the car chassis, along with axles, axle guides and wheels.

DESIGN: Teams can create their own body shell - designing front and rear wings, as well as side pods, to turn it into a real F1 style car.

ANALYSE: Students can use the STEM Racing Air Trace Visualisation System to visually assess the aerodynamics of the car by the flow of air around it.

MAKE: As the car body is made from card, pupils can use scissors or a cutter plotter to cut their chosen shapes, before they are glued together.

TEST: For in-school testing, an STEM Racing roll-out racetrack is ideal.

RACE: At competition, cars are raced on a 20-metre elevated racetrack, powered by 4 gram cannisters of compressed air.

PROJECT MANAGEMENNT: A Unit of Work explains the basic principles of project management and how to apply them.

THE REQUIREMENTS

When competing in an STEM RACING event, teams will be assessed on:

DESIGN & ENGINEERING

PORTFOLIO: A five-page document discussing topics such as design development and manufacturing processes.

VERBAL PRESENTATION: Lasting five minutes, teams should discuss their learning experiences and project management processes.

SCRUTINEERING: Prior to racing, cars will be assessed for compliance with the technical regulations which specify details such as minimum and maximum dimensions and weight restrictions.

DESIGN

MAKE

ASSEMBLE

TEST

RACE

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

PRIVACY POLICY

Privacy Policy

This Privacy Notice is for the below websites which are managed by STEM RACINNG Limited and Engineering in Motion Limited

  • Stemracing.com
  • stemracinng.co.uk
  • engineeringinmotion.com

Purpose of this Privacy Notice This Privacy Notice aims to give you information on how STEM Racing Limited and Engineering in Motion Limited collects and processes your personal data through your interactions with us and through your use of this website, including any data you may provide when you leave a message, sign up for a newsletter, or enter a challenge. We have appointed a Privacy Manager who is responsible for overseeing questions in relation to this Privacy Notice. If you have any questions about this Privacy Notice, including any requests to exercise your legal rights, please contact the Privacy Manager using the details set out below.

Contact details Full name of legal entity: Engineering in Motion Limited Correspondence should be addressed to the Privacy Manager Email address: dataprivacy@engineeringinmotion.org.uk Postal address: Armytage Road, Brighouse, West Yorkshire, England HD6 1QF

How we use personal data Engineering in Motion LTD shall only use personal data collected during your use of this website in accordance with all relevant UK Data Protection legislation and European General Data Protection Regulations [GDPR]. How is your personal data collected? We may collect personal information submitted to us including name, gender, mailing address, email address, telephone number, and any other information specifically sent to us. As you interact with our websites, we may automatically collect information about your website browsing actions and patterns. We collect this personal data by using cookies. Please see our Cookie Policy. Engineering in Motion Limited does not collect sensitive data, such as race, religion, or political affiliations via its websites. Where a user is under the age of 13, the information will only be obtained from a parent/guardian or teacher and cannot be provided by the young person.

How we use your personal data Any personal data supplied to us may be used to communicate with you or your team/teacher to let you know about changes to the challenge, offerings from Engineering in Motion Limited, and our partners or for market research purposes. If you do not wish us to contact you for these purposes, please email us at dataprivacy@engineeringinmotion.org.uk or follow the unsubscribe links in our email communications.

Disclosures of your personal data We will not sell, share, trade, or license any of your personal information to others without your express consent. However, we reserve the right to disclose your information if requested by the Police or Government authority in connection with any investigations concerning your activities while visiting the site.

Data Security We will make all reasonable efforts to safeguard the security of your information, but please be aware that we cannot guarantee the security or transmission of data over the internet. Engineering in Motion Limited takes every precaution to protect users' information from unauthorized access, use, or disclosure in accordance with the Data Protection Act. Access to personal information is given to our employees where necessary in the execution of their duties, and all employees who have access to personal data or are associated with the handling of that data are obliged to respect the confidentiality of that data.

Data Storage Some or all of your data may be stored outside of the European Economic Area (“the EEA”) (The EEA consists of all EU member states, plus Norway, Iceland, and Liechtenstein). You are deemed to accept and agree to this by using our site and submitting information to us. If we do store data outside the EEA, we will take all reasonable steps to ensure that your data is treated as safely and securely as it would be within the UK and under the General Data Protection Regulations. Personal data will remain confidential and will ONLY be used for the purpose it was submitted, this being the F1 in Schools competition season. Data will be kept on our systems for six months following the world final event date to facilitate certain post-season communication. Following this, it will be deleted.

Third Party Data Processors We use the following third-party data processors:

  • Customer Relationship Management Software (CRM) We use a CRM database to manage all personal data we hold. The software we use is called Maximixer CRM Live. This software is cloud-based and accessed by our staff via an individual password-protected user login. Only staff that need to process data have access and have been fully trained with our personal data policy. If you have signed up for our newsletters, registered for our competitions via our websites, or handed us your contact card, your details will be securely stored on our CRM database. Maximixer CRM Live is GDPR compliant, and their privacy policy can be found at: www.maximizer.com/legal/privacy-policy/
  • Email Services We use Microsoft Cloud and Microsoft Exchange Online for our standard email communications. This software is cloud-based and accessed by our staff via an individual password-protected user login. Microsoft Cloud and Microsoft Exchange Online are GDPR compliant, and their privacy policy can be found at: https://privacy.microsoft.com/en-GB/
  • Dotmailer When we communicate with you electronically, we use an email mailing list program. The provider we use is Dotmailer. Contact details stored on our CRM are migrated to Dotmailer, which then handles our messaging. Users can unsubscribe at any time through an automated online service, or if not available, other means as detailed in the footer of sent marketing messages. This software is accessed via an individual password-protected user login. Only staff that need to process data have access and have been fully trained with our personal data policy. Email marketing messages may contain tracking beacons/tracked clickable links or similar server technologies to track subscriber activity within email marketing messages. Where used, such marketing messages may record a range of subscriber data relating to engagement, geographic, demographics, and already stored subscriber data. Dotmailer is GDPR compliant, and their privacy policy can be found at: www.dotmailer.com/terms/privacy-policy/
  • Smartsheet.com We use smartsheet.com as our primary data capture solution for event-specific data capture. Once submitted, data is transferred into our CRM database. Data is only held on smartsheet.com for as long as necessary in relevance to the specific reason it was submitted. This software is accessed via an individual password-protected user login. Only staff that need to process data have access and have been fully trained with our personal data policy. Smartsheet.com is GDPR compliant, and their privacy policy can be found at: www.smartsheet.com/legal/privacy

Your Legal Rights Under certain circumstances, you have rights under data protection laws in relation to your personal data. Please see below under “Your Legal Rights” to find out more about these rights. If you wish to exercise any of the rights set out below, please contact us using the details given above. You have the right to ask for a copy of any of your personal data held by us (where such data is held). You will not have to pay a fee to access your personal data (or to exercise any of the other rights). However, we may charge a reasonable fee if your request is clearly unfounded, repetitive, or excessive. Alternatively, we may refuse to comply with your request in these circumstances.

What we need from you We may need to request specific information from you to help us confirm your identity and ensure your right to access your personal data (or to exercise any of your other rights). This is a security measure to ensure that personal data is not disclosed to any person who has no right to receive it. We may also contact you to ask you for further information in relation to your request to speed up our response.

Time of limit to respond We try to respond to all legitimate requests within one month. Occasionally it may take us longer than a month if your request is particularly complex or you have made a number of requests. In this case, we will notify you and keep you updated.

Cookies You can set your browser to refuse all or some browser cookies or to alert you when websites set or access cookies. If you disable or refuse cookies, please note that some parts of this website may become inaccessible or not function properly. For more information about cookies we use, please see our cookie policy. [Click Here]

Third-party links to related sites This website may include links to third-party websites, plug-ins, and applications. Clicking on those links or enabling those connections may allow third parties to collect or share data about you. We do not control these third-party websites and are not responsible for their privacy statements. When you leave our website, we encourage you to read the privacy notice of every website you visit.

Downloads & Media Files Any downloadable documents, files, or media made available on this website are provided to users at their own risk. While all precautions have been undertaken to ensure only genuine downloads are available, users are advised to verify their authenticity using third-party anti-virus software or similar applications. We accept no responsibility for third-party downloads and downloads provided by external third-party websites, and we advise users to verify their authenticity using third

© COPYRIGHT ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

    • CONTACT

PROFESSIONAL CLASS -14 TO 19

The most advanced stage of the competition, Professional Class is where students are able to truly showcase their innovative thinking.

WHAT'S INVOLVED

With (almost) complete design freedom and intricate technical regulations, there are new challenges:

DESIGN: Cars must now include a halo and virtual cargo, and students are able to design everything from wheels to nose cone, enabling them to fully explore the power of Autodesk Fusion software.

ANALYSE: Ansys CFD software is critical for design optimisation, with students required to perform rigorous tests to inform the limitless modifications possible in the design of their car

MAKE: Teams must once again CNC machine their car body using model block, and retain the ability to 3D print the wings.

TEST: CFD software is used to carry out various purposeful virtual tests, trialling the performance of the car, fully assembled and in individual components, before physical tests are performed.

RACE: Cars are raced on a 20-metre elevated racetrack, powered by 8 gram cannisters of compressed air.

PROJECT MANAGEMENNT: Teams follow, use, and evidence the processes detailed in the handbook.

THE REQUIREMENTS

When competing in an STEM RACING event, teams will be assessed on:

DESIGN & ENGINEERING PORTFOLIO: A ten-page document discussing topics including 3D modelling and design process evaluation.

ENTERPRISE PORTFOLIO: A ten-page document detailing a team’s marketing strategy, alongside its implementation of project management.

VERBAL PRESENTATION: Lasting ten minutes, teams will once again be assessed on technique, clarity, and content.

BRAND IDENTITY: The pit display plays a key role, as well as a team’s wider branding.

SCRUTINEERING: Due to the nature of the technical regulations, this assessment is exceptionally rigorous.

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

REGISTER

Join the STEM Racing Challenge!

Are you ready to test your skills and compete with the best young minds in engineering, design, and innovation? STEM Racing invites students from around the world to join this thrilling competition. For now, registration is managed locally. Visit the Country List section on our website to find the contact details of your national coordinator. They’ll guide you through the process of registering and getting started on your journey to becoming a STEM Racing champion.


Exciting news is on the horizon! Soon, we’ll launch the STEM Racing Global Registration System.

This platform will revolutionize the way teams compete, allowing students to register directly, track their progress, and connect with other participants worldwide.



​Stay tuned for updates and get ready to drive innovation like never before!
