how stem racing is driving change: impact report 24/25

At the beginning of this year, we launched our new identity: STEM Racing, Supported by Formula 1. This rebrand has taken us into an exciting new era and, as we reflect on a landmark year, we are proud to share our Impact Report for 2024/25.

​A celebration of all we have achieved over the past 12 months - from a phenomenal World Finals in Saudi Arabia to the launch of STEM Racing in Kenya, South Africa, Mali and Togo - we hope you enjoy recapping our incredible journey so far.

world finals 2024

​Held at Dhahran Expo, Saudi Arabia, the 2024 Aramco STEM Racing World Finals brought together 450+ students and educators from 25 countries. Over 55 teams competed in a three-day celebration of innovation, design, and engineering.

    Key Moments:

  • Dates: 23–26 November 2024
  • Winners: Team evolut1on, Germany
  • Special Guest: Fernando Alonso presented awards
  • Engineering Academy: 10 students selected for Komatsu-Williams programme
  • Diversity: 1 in 3 participants were female.

“We spent two years and thousands of hours on this. To win among so many talented teams is incredible.”

Theo Paulsen,
Team Manager, evolut1on (World Champions)

GLOBAL REACH - LOCAL IMPACT

In 2024, STEM Racing gave more students hands-on access to engineering, technology and motorsport than ever before — powered by our partnership with Formula 1®.

    Key Highlights:

  • 13 Grand Prix activations
  • ​300+ students with exclusive paddock access
  • STEM Racing installations at major industry events
  • 700-person pit-lane walk at Qatar Grand Prix

Paddock Tours took place at:
Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Australia, China, Miami, Monaco, UK, Hungary, Singapore, Austin, Qatar, Abu Dhabi, Mexico

Qatar Grand Prix Spotlight:
One of our largest activations to date – a 700-person pit-lane walk offering students a rare, behind-the-scenes look at the world of F1®.

OPENING DOORS TO STEM CAREERS

In 2024, we expanded access to STEM education by:

  1. Engaging diverse students from across the globe
  2. Partnering with leading teams and foundations
  3. Delivering hands-on experiences that spark ambition

Key Highlights:

  • 120 students joined Make A Mark with Aston Martin at Silverstone.
  • ​Karting activations with Fernando Alonso in China and Spain.
  • STEM sessions in Miami Gardens introducing local communities to engineering.
  • Workshops in Shanghai with Aston Martin, Aramco, Pedro de la Rosa and Jessica Hawkins.
  • Leadership workshop with Aleto Foundation and Aston Martin for underrepresented young talent.
  • Free STEM Racing kits delivered in Soweto with Empower Young Learners and Kliptown Youth Program (KYP).

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

ARAMCO STEM RACING WORLD FINALS 2025

Rules & Regulations

SINGAPORE WORLD FINALS TECHNICAL REGULATIONS 2025 ​REVISION 2​

SR25WF_Technical_Regulations_Revision 2

DOWNLOAD FILE

SINGAPORE WORLD FINALS COMPETiTION REGULATIONS 2025

SR25WF_competetition_regulations

DOWNLOAD FILE

Project Management Guide - 2024/25

In 2019, STEM Racing partnered with the Project Management Institute Educational Foundation (PMIEF) and totogether we have developed the STEM Racing Project Management guide. This document is intended to give teams an understanding of the fundamental principles of Project Management and how to use these to deliver their STEM Racing entry.

To credit the Project Management skills and processes used by teams, the World Finals 2024 Competition Regulations will contain a ‘Project Management’ scorecard. It is very important that teams carefully read this new section and ensure their Project Management methodology and processes are evidenced clearly, as per the scorecard.

stem_racing_-_project_management_guide_2025.pdf

DOWNLOAD FILE

​If you’re not sure, ask!

If, after sitting down and reading through the whole document, you still are not clear on how the competition will run in 2025, please just get in touch with the team using the contact details below and we will do out best to answer any queries. Remember, we’re here for you and all the changes we’ve made this year are to help make 2025 the best year ever for the competition, the teams and everyone involved. See you at the World Finals!

STEM Racing Challenge

rules@stemracing.com

sponsorship

Partner with STEM Racing and Drive the Future!

STEM Racing is more than a competition—it’s a global movement inspiring the next generation of innovators, engineers, and problem-solvers. As a non-profit organization, we rely on the support of forward-thinking companies like yours to expand this challenge and empower students worldwide.
By partnering with STEM Racing, your company will:

  • Support Global Education: Help young minds access cutting-edge STEM opportunities, fostering talent and innovation in every corner of the world.
  • Build Brand Impact: Align your brand with a cause that transforms lives and inspires future leaders in science, technology, and engineering.
  • Tailored Collaboration: We create custom sponsorship plans designed to meet your company’s goals and maximize your involvement in this inspiring initiative.

Join us in driving STEM education to new heights. Get in touch today to explore how we can partner and make a lasting impact together!

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

With 83 teams from 34 countries all competing in the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals 2025, there's some fantastic stories of innovation, dedication and talent to celebrate

TO1:EXCELERATE RACING COUNTRY: SINGAPORE SCHOOL: XCL WORLD ACADEMY

XCLerate Racing, from Singapore, is a six-member team aged 17. Formed to represent Singapore at the 2023 World Finals, they became National Champions in 2024. Their name combines “accelerate” and “XCL,” their school sponsor. Their car, XCL-Lithium, is named for reliability and solid performance, inspired by the Greek word “lithos.”

Development began after the 2024 Nationals, with six months of simulation and testing. Challenges included balancing IB studies with competition, solved through shared schedules and communication tools. Innovations include airflow redirection using wheel inertia and Assetto Corsa mods for sim racing. XCLerate Racing is unique for its strong school identity and national representation. Their proudest moment was winning Nationals with only two members present. Dream careers include engineering, fintech, and sustainable technologies. Their favourite moment was being interviewed on national radio, sharing their journey and inspiring others.

@xclerate_racing​

T02: CHANGE HOLDINGS Hayabusa Racing Country: JAPAN School: Independent Team

Based in Minato-ku, Japan, Hayabusa Racing is an independent team formed in January 2024. Led by Rona, a returning World Finals competitor, the team comprises six male students aged 16–17. Without school backing, they became Japan’s first fully sponsor-funded team. The name “Hayabusa” reflects speed and precision, inspired by the peregrine falcon and Japan’s bullet train. Their car, HB03, evolved from prototypes “Thunderbolt” and “Beyonder.”

Development began earlier this year, with major obstacles including low sponsorship response and lack of workspace. They overcame these through A/B testing, networking, and professional guidance. Hayabusa Racing stands out for its unique marketing, project management, and engineering approach, including genetic algorithms and race-start devices. Their mission is to promote project-based learning in Japan. Highlights include visiting Honda’s Sakura Factory and meeting F1 drivers. Their dream careers span engineering, aerospace, and entrepreneurship.

@_hayabusaracing​

T03: Ascent Country: Germany School: Gymnasium Grootmoor​

Ascent, from Gymnasium Grootmoor in Hamburg, Germany, is a six-member team aged 15–17. Formed in August 2024, they quickly rose through the ranks, winning regional and national awards including fastest car and best CAD. Their name, “Ascent,” reflects their goal to climb through competition levels and improve daily. Their car, Arrow3, continues a legacy of speed and precision. Though they don’t have a mascot, their logo features an upward-pointing arrow. Development began after the German National Finals in May. Funding was a challenge, but they secured sponsors in time. Innovations include an air-powered ball bearing testing system and a pit display racing game inspired by the Singapore Grand Prix. Ascent is unique for their clear organisation and optimistic approach, despite being in their first STEM Racing season.

@ascent.racing​

T04: SBA Unity RacING Country: UNITED KINGDOM School: Scarborough University Technical College

SBA Unity Racing, from Scarborough, UK, is a dedicated team representing Scarborough Business Ambassadors. Comprising students with a passion for STEM and motorsport, they have steadily progressed through regional and national competitions. Their car, developed through months of teamwork and innovation, reflects their commitment to precision and performance. The team overcame challenges such as funding constraints and technical setbacks by fostering resilience and collaboration.

Notable innovations include advanced engineering solutions and a focus on sustainability. What makes SBA Unity Racing unique is their strong community spirit and drive to inspire future generations in Scarborough. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals, a testament to their hard work and determination. The team aspires to careers in engineering, business, and technology, and their favourite STEM Racing moment was celebrating their achievements together, united by a shared vision for success.

@sba.unity.racing

T05: Absolute Racing Country: China

Absolute Racing, from Beijing, China, is a six-member all-male team aged 16–17. Formed as a successor to Wings Racing, they carry a decade-long legacy in STEM Racing. Their name, “Absolute,” translates from the Chinese word “jue dui,” symbolising certainty and timeless excellence. Their car, Red Swallow, is inspired by the swallow’s speed and cultural significance, with its tail design resembling the bird’s silhouette. Their mascot, the Beijing Swallow, appears throughout their branding.

​Development spanned 93 days, with obstacles including schoolwork and TOEFL exams. They adapted by prioritising tasks and supporting each other. Innovations include integrating modern project management with traditional Chinese strategy, wind tunnel testing, and mathematical modelling. Absolute Racing is unique for its mission to define car culture in China. Their proudest moment was connecting with Jim Glickenhaus during sponsorship outreach. Dream roles include dual careers in car design and engineering. Their favourite moment was winning at Nationals.

@absoluteracing_sdsz

T06: Ad Astra Country: Australia SCHOOL: Brighton Grammar School

Ad Astra, from Brighton Grammar School in Australia, is a six-member team aged 14–16. Their name, Latin for “to the stars,” reflects ambition and resilience. Formed in late 2023, they’ve rapidly progressed from State Champions to World Finalists. Their car, Stella, symbolises guidance and excellence. Though they lack a mascot, their innovations shine - most notably, a Rear Wing Design Competition involving primary schools, now featured in their pit display.

​Funding was a major hurdle, overcome through teamwork and outreach. Ad Astra’s strength lies in their unity and rapid ascent through competition levels. Their favourite experience has been meeting diverse teams and mentors across Australia. Dream careers include F1 engineering, strategy, and mechanics. Their journey from States to Nationals to Worlds in one campaign showcases their determination and collaborative spirit.

@adastraracing

T07: ALPHA SCUDERIA SESI SENAI SC Country: Brazil SCHOOL: Escola SESI Criciúma​​

ALPHA SCUDERIA, from Criciúma, Brazil, is a veteran team with a rich history in STEM Racing. Competing since 2020, they’ve earned awards for engineering, sustainability, and collaboration. Their name redefines “Alpha” as empathetic leadership, inspired by modern wolf pack research. Their car, W25-S, continues a naming tradition tied to year and location. Their mascot, Alphie - a pink and purple wolf - adds personality to their branding. Over six months, they developed their car while navigating stakeholder engagement, storytelling challenges, and supplier coordination. Innovations span software, engineering prototypes, and sustainability projects.

ALPHA SCUDERIA is unique for its legacy-driven approach and social impact. Their proudest moment was winning the National Finals 2025 after years of striving. Team members aspire to careers in engineering, marketing, and communication. They’re driven by a desire to leave a lasting legacy in STEM Racing.

@​alpha.scuderia

T08: Daedalus Racing Country: Greece SCHOOL: Mandoulides Schools, Erasmeios Greek and German School, Ekpedeftiki Anagennisi

Daedalus Racing, based in Attica, Greece, is a collaborative team formed from three schools separated by over 500 kilometres. Despite the distance, they’ve built strong unity and a shared passion for motorsport. Their name, inspired by the myth of Daedalus, reflects creativity and ambition. Their car, also named Daedalus, symbolises speed and invention. Development began in April, with obstacles including limited access to race tracks. They overcame this by creating a Python programme to predict race times.

​Innovations include a regulation-checking software, performance predictor, and smart testing tools. Daedalus Racing is unique for its outreach work, inspiring hundreds of students through STEM presentations and events. Their proudest achievement is hosting ten educational sessions and partnering with Circuit 27, Greece’s largest racetrack. Dream careers range from engineering to sports medicine and design. Their favourite moment was connecting with karting experts and building friendships through STEM Racing.

@daedalus_.racing

T09: Atalanta Racing Country: Cyprus SCHOOL: American Academy Larnaca​

Atalanta Racing, from Larnaca, Cyprus, is a six-member team aged 17–18. Formed in September 2024, they became national champions in 2025. Their name honours the Greek goddess of speed, reflecting resilience and cultural pride. Their car, Goddess Atalanta, was developed over three months. Challenges included limited funding and suppliers, overcome through strategic resource management and international sourcing.

​Innovations include forward-lofted front wing endplates to optimise finish-line detection and airflow. Atalanta Racing is unique for its identity-driven approach and commitment to excellence. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals. Dream careers include project management and engineering. Their favourite moment was submitting their final deliverables, marking the culmination of their efforts.

@atalanta.racing

T10: NAGA Racing Country: Kuwait SCHOOL: SACGC​

NAGA Racing, from Shuwakh, Kuwait, is a six-member team aged 14–17. Formed three months ago, they won first place at Nationals in their debut season. Their name, “NAGA,” refers to a serpent symbolising strength and resilience, rooted in Kuwaiti culture. Their car, NR-X1, is internally named for version tracking.

​Development began post-Nationals, with a month and a half of refinement. Challenges included competition delays, technical issues, and personal emergencies, overcome through coordination and extra effort. Innovations include a new wing design, recycled uniforms, and heritage-inspired branding. NAGA Racing is unique for its cultural integration and sustainability focus. Their proudest moment was winning Nationals and hosting Kuwait’s Prime Minister. Dream careers include roles in Formula 1 across engineering, marketing, and design. Their favourite moment was competing at Nationals and gaining national recognition, proving their potential on the global stage.

@nagaracingkw

T11: APEX Elegance Country: Macau SCHOOL: Macao Science Center​

Apex Elegance, the first international STEM Racing team from Macau, was founded in August 2024. Their name blends “Apex” for precision and “Elegance” for refined execution, reflecting their design philosophy: “Simple. Complex. Elegant.” Their car, Zenith, symbolises peak performance. Their mascot, a royal purple cat, adds charm and agility to their branding. Over eight months, they developed a modular pit display and sustainable materials, solving transport challenges with clever design.

​Their innovations include recycled tea leaf boards, parameterised CAD, and analytics-driven project management. Apex Elegance stands out for merging Macau’s racing heritage with modern sustainability. Their proudest moment was outperforming top teams with an unfinished car that ran the fastest time of the day. Team members aim for careers in engineering and design. Their journey proves that resilience and preparation can turn setbacks into triumphs.

T12: Blitz Racing Country: Ireland SCHOOL: Marist College Athlone​

Blitz Racing, from Athlone, Ireland, is a three-member all-male team aged 17–18. Formed in late 2024, they won the Irish National Finals and Best Pit Display. Their name, “Blitz,” means lightning in German, symbolising speed and power. Their car, Sionna MK.2, is named after the Irish goddess of the River Shannon, connecting their design to local heritage.

​Development involved over 130 hours of CAD modelling and extensive testing. Innovations include a unique three-ramp front wing and strategic virtual cargo placement. Blitz Racing is unique for its bold branding and cultural integration. Their proudest moment was winning Nationals. Dream careers include aerospace engineering, medicine, and design. Their favourite moment was hearing their name announced as champions, validating their hard work.

@blitzracing2024

T13: SVT Racing Country: Thailand SCHOOL: King's College International School Bangkok

SVT Racing, from Bangkok, Thailand, is a five-member team aged 16–17. Formed through the FOBISIA STEM competition, they placed in the top three at Nationals. Their name comes from the physics equation s = vt, symbolising speed and efficiency. Their car, Black Necromancer, is inspired by Star Wars and reflects their ambition to create an impossibly fast design.

​Development spanned over seven months, with challenges in engineering skill gaps, resolved through training. Innovations include underbody fins applying Bernoulli’s principle for improved traction. SVT Racing is unique for its close-knit team dynamic and shared classroom history. Their proudest moment was producing their first World Finals car. Dream careers include theoretical physics and engineering. Their favourite moment was drawing inspiration from Team Infinitude’s world record car, motivating them to push boundaries.

@svtracingf1

T14: TONALTECH Country: Mexico SCHOOL: Escuela Preparatoria Regional de Tonalá Norte​

TONALTECH, from Tonalá, Mexico, is a five-member team aged 17–19. Competing since 2016, they’ve won six national championships and two international awards. Their name combines “Tonalá” and “Tech,” reflecting their mission to inspire youth through technology. Their car, Maxa, is named after the Wixárika word for deer, symbolising speed and cultural heritage.

​Development began in April, with challenges in weight reduction, solved through extensive testing. Innovations include rear chevrons to reduce turbulence and improve airflow. TONALTECH is unique for its community commitment, aiming to leave a legacy for future teams. Their proudest moment was receiving the FIA Women in Motorsport Award and seeing their community celebrate their success. Dream careers include automotive engineering and racing. Their favourite moment was racing together and feeling the pride of representing their region.

@tonaltech

T15: ACERSWIFT Country: Malaysia SCHOOL: Kolej Yayasan Saad Melaka​

ACERSWIFT, from Kolej Yayasan Saad Melaka in Malaysia, is a team of six 16-year-olds who’ve spent three years building their STEM Racing journey. Formed from classmates with diverse backgrounds and personalities, they overcame geographical and interpersonal challenges to qualify for the World Finals. Their name blends “Ace” and “Swift,” symbolising precision and speed. Their car, Ace-5, is the fifth iteration of their design legacy. The team’s mascot, a snake, represents agility and wisdom.

​Innovations include an RFID-based Instagram keychain made from recycled plastic. ACERSWIFT stands out for its skill diversity - musicians, athletes, debaters, and scouts all contribute to a dynamic team culture. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals, a goal once considered impossible. They aspire to careers in engineering, medicine, and design, and cherish the collaborations they’ve built with universities and companies along the way.

@kys.acerswift

T17: ASAP Racing Country: Canada SCHOOL:Pensionnat Saint-Nom-de-Marie

ASAP Racing, from Montreal, Canada, is a five-member all-female team aged 16. Formed in June 2024, they placed second at Nationals and won six awards, including Best Engineered Car and Sustainability. Their name reflects urgency and empowerment, with a nod to feminism and Maria Teresa de Filippis. Development began in June 2025, with obstacles including resin shortages, solved through material substitution.

​Innovations include self-made magazines documenting their journey and a pit display that tells their story. ASAP Racing is unique for its spirit of growth and passion over results. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals and proving their dedication. Dream careers include engineering, business, and media. Their favourite moment was realising their efforts led to national recognition, inspiring them to continue pushing boundaries and representing women in STEM.

@asap_racing_4

T18: Hermes Racing Country: United Arab Emirates SCHOOL: Raha International School Gardens Campus​

Hermes Racing, from Abu Dhabi, UAE, is a four-member team aged 16–17. With four years of experience, they’ve competed in two World Finals and earned awards for marketing and engineering. Their name reflects Hermes, the messenger god, symbolising creativity and collaboration. Their car, Caduceus, was developed over three months. A major challenge was balancing schoolwork with competition deadlines, which they overcame through mentorship and scheduling.

​Innovations include aerodynamic dimples and green energy initiatives. Hermes Racing is unique for its resilience and ability to collaborate remotely, especially during summer when the team was geographically separated. Their proudest moment was filming digital media content and partnering with a sustainability-focused company. Dream careers include film direction, engineering, and business leadership. Their favourite moment was the team photo at the World Finals pitlane, celebrating unity after competition.

@officialhermesracing

T19: Sadu Racing Country: Kuwait SCHOOL: SACGC​

Sadu Racing, from Shuwakh, Kuwait, is a six-member team aged 15–17. Formed in 2025, they placed second at Nationals in their debut season. Their name, “Sadu,” reflects Kuwaiti heritage and ambition. Development began in August, with challenges including bearing misfits and budget limitations, solved through redesign and sponsorship outreach.

​Innovations include Sadu-pattern branding, lightweight axle systems, and sustainable marketing. Sadu Racing is unique for blending tradition with STEM innovation, representing both cultural pride and technical progress. Their proudest moment was completing their car and qualifying for the World Finals. Dream careers include engineering and project management. Their favourite moment was watching their car race for the first time, a powerful symbol of achievement and teamwork. Sadu Racing aims to inspire future generations in Kuwait through STEM Racing and collaboration.

@sadu_racing

T20: DriftX Racing Country: Korea, Republic of SCHOOL: St. Johnsbury Academy Jeju​

DriftX Racing, from Jeju Island, South Korea, is a six-member team aged 16–17. Though newly formed, members bring experience in engineering, design, and marketing. Their name reflects a desire to redefine motorsport in Korea, with “Drift” symbolising bold direction and “X” the unknown potential. Their car design draws inspiration from traditional Korean art, and development spanned four months.

​Challenges included shipping delays and team absences, overcome through early planning and task distribution. Innovations include aerodynamic testing and a unique wing design. DriftX Racing is proud of its cultural identity, integrating Korean heritage into every aspect of the project. Their proudest moment was being selected to represent Korea at the World Finals. Dream careers include engineering, design, and economics. Their favourite moment was seeing their printed car for the first time - a symbol of teamwork and national pride.

@driftx_racing_

T21: IKEUCHI Fusion Force CountrIES: Japan & Thailand SCHOOLS: The American School in Japan, Satit Bilingual School of Rangsit University, Lertlah School

IKEUCHI Fusion Force is a six-member all-male team aged 12–16, formed through collaboration between schools in Japan and Thailand. Founded in April, they qualified for the World Finals after winning awards at the Thai Nationals. Their name, “Fusion Force,” symbolises unity across cultures and determination. Their car, Rook, is named after the chess piece, reflecting strategic strength.

​Development lasted four months, with challenges in sponsorship, solved through emotional storytelling and live presentations. Innovations include a unique verbal presentation concept and rapid car development. Fusion Force is unique for its international makeup and rapid progress. Their proudest moment was securing sponsorships and building a high-performing car. Dream careers include roles in Formula 1, engineering, and marketing. Their favourite moment was winning the knockout competition in Thailand.

@fusionforce.sr

T22: Giddam Racing Country: Saudi Arabia SCHOOL: STEM Racing Saudi​​

Giddam Racing, from Khobar, Saudi Arabia, is a six-member team aged 15–17. Formed with the motto “Always one step GIDDAM,” they’ve competed for two years, earning recognition for marketing and engineering. Their name means “forward” in Arabic, symbolising speed and progress. Their car, Cupcake, and mascot, Giddamer, reflect their playful yet focused identity.

​Development spanned nine months, with challenges in time management, sponsorship, and manufacturing. Innovations include aerodynamic wing profiles, eco-friendly materials, and interactive marketing strategies. Giddam Racing is unique for blending local culture with global standards, and for their strong teamwork and branding. Their proudest moments include securing sponsorships and seeing their car race successfully. Dream careers include engineering, marketing, and creative direction. Their favourite moment was launching their social media and seeing real engagement, proving their identity resonated with others.

@giddamracing

T23: JetPlex Racing Country: Poland SCHOOL: I Liceum Ogólnokształcące im. Stanisława Staszica w Pleszewie​

JetPlex Racing, from Pleszew, Poland, is a four-member team aged 17–18. Founded in December 2023, they won the Polish National Championship in July 2024, securing their place at the World Finals. Their name combines “Jet” for CO₂ propulsion and “Plex” for their hometown. Their car, JetEagle, is inspired by Poland’s national emblem, the white eagle.

​Development spanned 10 months, with challenges including fragile 3D prints and currency fluctuations. Innovations include in-house 3D printing, CNC access, and digital project management tools. JetPlex Racing stands out for its social responsibility, including tree planting to offset carbon emissions and outreach to children’s homes. Their proudest moment was showcasing their project at the Poznań Motor Show. Dream careers include engineering, psychology, and entrepreneurship. Their favourite moment was organising a Christmas charity event, demonstrating their commitment to community impact.

@jetplexracing

T24: ICARUS Country: Luxembour SCHOOL: European School Luxembourg 2​

ICARUS, from Luxembourg, is a five-member team aged 17–19, representing European School Luxembourg 2. Formed in 2022, they’ve competed in three National Finals and won awards for fastest car, best logo, and judges’ favourite. Their name, inspired by Greek mythology, reflects ambition and calculated risk. Their car, C19c, is the third iteration of the C19 model. Though they lack a mascot, their pit display is highly innovative - built from aluminium profiles that double as a transport case.

​Development began in July, with challenges including poorly documented thermal setups, solved through power supply adjustments. ICARUS is unique for its international diversity, with members from Czechia, Croatia, and Greece. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals, representing Luxembourg on the global stage. Dream careers include automotive testing, IT, aerodynamics, law, and finance. Their favourite moment was winning the Judges’ Favourite award at their first event.

@icarusluxembourg

T25: Hammer Team Country: Italy SCHOOL: Liceo Scientifico Lorenzo Respighi​

Hammer Team, from Piacenza, Italy, is a five-member team aged 18. Formed in November 2023, they won the National Championship and qualified for the World Finals. Their name is inspired by Lewis Hamilton’s “Hammer Time” radio call, symbolising determination and peak performance. Their car, CR-02, continues a naming tradition linked to an inside joke about a fictional driver. Their unofficial mascot is Harry, a cheerful dog belonging to their marketing manager.

​Development began in January, with intense testing from August. Challenges included coordinating with multiple partners and tight deadlines, solved through data analysis and strategic planning. Innovations include social media collaborations with F2 drivers and refined engineering with F1 experts. Hammer Team is unique for its spontaneity and collaborative spirit. Their proudest moment was presenting at Expo 2025 in Osaka. Dream careers include engineering and marketing. Their favourite moment was winning Nationals at Dallara.

@_hammer.team_

T26: HAWK RACING QUERÉTARO Country: Mexico SCHOOL: Tec Milenio Querétaro​

HAWK RACING QUERÉTARO, from Santiago de Querétaro, Mexico, is a six-member team aged 17–19. Formed in early 2024, they won the Development Class National Finals in their first season. Their name reflects vision, strategy, and pride in representing their state. Their car, HR 5 – Spartan LT, honours their first design and features a long tail.

​Development spanned over a year, with challenges in sponsorship, solved through fundraising and community support. Innovations include a handcrafted carbon fibre rear wing and geometric deviation analysis. HAWK RACING is unique for its diversity and resilience. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals. Dream careers include working in Formula 1 and the automotive industry. Their favourite moment was watching last year’s award ceremony, inspiring their journey.

@hawk.racing.qro

T27: Increvex Country: Ireland SCHOOL: St. Brigids College Loughrea​

INCREVEX, from County Galway, Ireland, is a four-member all-female team aged 17–18. Formed in 2023, they placed second at Nationals and won awards for fastest car and best engineering. Their name combines “Incrementum” (Latin for growth) and “väx” (Swedish for grow), symbolising innovation and progress. Development spanned 16 months, with challenges balancing school and competition.

​Innovations include a subtly engineered car design and a strong team identity. INCREVEX is unique for its focus on female empowerment and STEM outreach. Their proudest moment was securing a €20,000 CNC machine for their school, leaving a legacy for future students. Dream careers include managing an all-female F1 team. Their favourite moment was securing sponsorship from Valeo, a thrilling milestone that made their World Finals journey possible.

@increvex

T28: Eclipse Country: Australia SCHOOL: Wesley College​

Eclipse, from Wesley College in Perth, Australia, is a six-member team aged 14–17. Competing since 2023, they’ve won multiple awards at State and National levels, including fastest lap and best engineered car. Their name reflects rarity and impact, aiming to leave a mark on STEM Racing. Their car, Dawnbreaker, symbolises new beginnings and disruption.

​Development began in June, with major setbacks including a broken CNC machine, which they repaired themselves. Innovations include Eclipse AI, a regulation-navigating tool built using Copilot and trained on official documents. Eclipse is unique for its dedication, often working late into the night and sacrificing free time to perfect their car. Their proudest achievement was placing second at the 2025 Australian Nationals, climbing seven places from the previous year. Dream careers span various Formula 1 roles. Their favourite moment was being selected for Team Australia at the World Finals.

@eclipse.wa

T29: Siam AI Arun Racing Country: Thailand SCHOOL: International Community School & King’s College International School Bangkok

Siam AI Arun Racing, from Bangkok, Thailand, is a six-member team aged 14–15. Formed six months ago, they were selected as a wildcard team for the World Finals. Their name, “Arun,” means sunrise in Thai, symbolising new beginnings and growth. Their car, Blaze, reflects speed and passion, while their digital avatars serve as mascots.

Development began in April, with a major challenge being the departure of their design engineer. They overcame this by training both engineers to collaborate on the final design. Innovations include a self-tightening axle system for improved reliability. Arun Racing is unique for its youth, energy, and determination to prove themselves. Their proudest moment was securing a title sponsor, which boosted morale and resources. Dream careers include corporate leadership and engineering. Their favourite moment was appearing on national television to promote STEM Racing and inspire future innovators.

@arun__racing

T30: Echo Racing Country: Germany SCHOOL: Theodor-Mommsen-Schule Bad Oldesloe

Echo Racing, from Bad Oldesloe, Germany, is a four-member team aged 17–18. Formed in 2023, they quickly rose through regional and national competitions, winning awards for engineering, design, and pit display. Their name, “Echo,” reflects speed and their connection to bats, a symbol from their shared primary school experience. Their car, Reverb, continues the theme, representing lasting impact. Their mascot, Foxi the bat, adds personality to their presentations.

​Development began in May, with a focus on weight reduction and precision. Innovations include a custom AI for testing and a steering system prototype. Echo Racing is unique for its calm, focused teamwork and strong branding, including a multilingual team anthem. Their proudest moment was winning the pit display award at Nationals. Dream careers include roles in Formula 1. Their favourite moment was the group photo at their first national finals, capturing the excitement of competition.

@echoracing.de

T31: Island Racing Team Country: Cyprus SCHOOL: The Island Private School of Limassol​

Island Racing Team, based in Limassol, Cyprus, is a five-member team from The Island Private School of Limassol. Representing Cyprus, the team brings together students with a shared passion for STEM and motorsport. Although details of their competition history and car development are limited, their participation in the 2025 STEM Racing World Finals marks a significant milestone.

With members aged between 13 and 18, including Tymur and Ermis as team managers, the team showcases a blend of youthful energy and leadership. Their collaborative spirit and international outlook reflect the values of their school and the broader STEM Racing community. Island Racing Team is proud to represent Cyprus on the global stage, aiming to make a lasting impression through innovation, teamwork, and determination.

T32: Sirius Scuderia Country: Brazil SCHOOL: Instituto Federal Do Paraná​​

Sirius Scuderia, from Curitiba, Brazil, is a six-member team aged 16–18. Founded in January 2024, they were inspired by Team Velos and quickly rose to prominence, winning the National Championship. Their name, “Sirius,” refers to the brightest star, symbolising brilliance and determination. Their car, SS-GolfStar, features a dimpled rear surface inspired by golf ball aerodynamics.

​Development began after Nationals, with challenges including team member dropouts and funding, resolved through a strategic merger and sponsorship outreach. Innovations include a lap time prediction model and portable reaction test system. Sirius Scuderia is unique for applying advanced aerodynamics and for being the only public school team among Brazil’s World Finalists. Their proudest moment was winning Nationals. Dream careers include motorsport engineering. Their favourite moment was seeing their hard work pay off during competition, strengthening their bond as teammates and friends.

@sirius_scuderia

T33: Instinct Racing Country: China

Instinct Racing, from Beijing, China, is a six-member team aged 16–18. Formed about a year ago, they placed third at Nationals and qualified for the World Finals. Their name reflects racing as a natural instinct. Their car is unnamed, and they do not have a mascot. Development lasted 2–3 months, with challenges in CNC manufacturing, solved through local partnerships.

​Instinct Racing is unique for its active mindset and cohesive teamwork. Their proudest moment was placing third nationally. Dream careers include working in Formula 1 or civil aviation. Their favourite moment was quietly polishing their car while listening to music—a peaceful reflection of their dedication.

@instinct_racing2025

T34: Aeros Racing Country: United States of America SCHOOL: Affiliated with University of Chicago Laboratory Schools​

Aeros Racing, from Chicago, USA, is a six-member team aged 15–18. Founded in 2022, they’ve won multiple national titles and placed 13th at the 2024 World Finals. Their name evolved from “Arrows” to “Aeros,” highlighting their focus on aerodynamics. Their car, AW-25, was developed using data-driven design and performance modelling.

​Development began after the 2024 World Finals, with challenges including sponsorship losses due to economic shifts. They pivoted to in-kind partnerships and mentorships. Innovations include a prong-based wheel support system, profitability models for scoring, and Earned Media Value strategies. Aeros Racing is unique for being entirely student-led, with no school funding. Their proudest moment was winning the knockout competition at Nationals. Dream careers include engineering, team management, and strategy. Their favourite moment was meeting Oscar Piastri and connecting with global teams, reinforcing their passion for motorsport and STEM outreach.

@aeros_racing

T35: INTECRA Country: Malaysia SCHOOL: SMK Seksyen 9, Shah Alam​​

INTECRA, from Shah Alam, Malaysia, is a five-member team aged 15–16. Formed a year ago, they’ve won regional and national awards, including Best Pit Display and Best Verbal Presentation. Their name stands for Intelligence, Technology, and a New Era. Their car, AEROBYTE X, reflects three years of development and refinement. Their mascot, Albert, is an AI assistant featured in their pit display and social media.

​Development followed a three-phase cycle: research, design, and manufacture. Challenges included CFD simulation bugs, solved through alternate solvers and validation scripts. Innovations include annealed halo components and interactive AI tools. INTECRA is unique for blending technical excellence with human-centred design. Their proudest moment was winning Best Verbal Presentation at Nationals. Dream careers include engineering, architecture, and AI development. Their favourite moment was witnessing a rare dead heat at Nationals, inspiring their pursuit of precision.

@intecra_f1

Their name symbolises unity, with the motto “The unity that drives us.” Their car, Gear SR-1, marks their debut on the global stage. Development began in March, with challenges including a failed paint job, resolved by remanufacturing the car in one week.

Innovations include a bearing testing mechanism to select optimal wheel components. TEAM GEAR ONE is unique for its perseverance and commitment to helping rookie teams. Their proudest moment was becoming Brazilian Vice-Champions. Dream careers include motorsport engineering and social impact roles. ​Development began in February, with challenges in manufacturing research, which they overcame through planning. Innovations include an aerodynamic floor and a custom project management system. Ladies First is unique for being Hong Kong’s first all-girls team and for their sustainability focus. Their proudest moment was winning Development Class. Dream careers include engineering, game design, and cybersecurity. Blue Wolves, from Backnang, Germany, is a six-member team aged 11–18. Competing since 2023, they’ve won the German Junior Championship twice and became the first Senior Class champions in 2025. Their name symbolises focus and teamwork, with “Blue” for calm precision and “Wolves” for unity. Their car, Blue Wolf 25.3, is the third version this season.

​Development lasted four months, with challenges in weight optimisation, solved through axle redesign. Innovations include 3D-printed rear jets and a steering system prototype. Blue Wolves are unique for their branding, including a multilingual team anthem and chatbot. Their proudest moment was winning Nationals. Dream careers include roles in Formula 1. Their favourite moment was the announcement of their qualification for the World Finals.

​Development lasted four months, with challenges in weight optimisation, solved through axle redesign. Innovations include 3D-printed rear jets and a steering system prototype. APEX Racing, from India, is a six-member all-male team aged 14–17. Established in 2020, they’ve consistently placed in the top 10 nationally and won the Fastest Car Award in 2024. Their name refers to the apex of a racing corner, symbolising precision and peak performance. Development of their car took 3–4 months, with major setbacks including the departure of their team manager and mentor.

​They rebuilt their car and deliverables from scratch, regaining momentum through full-day meetings and strategic social media growth. Innovations include a PET fusion machine for recycling plastic into filament, AI generative design, and MDF mini car kits. APEX Racing is unique for its resilience and ability to overcome critical challenges. Their proudest moment was completing all deliverables under pressure. @kuraforce

T69: Petrolina Apiron Country: Cyprus SCHOOL: American Academy Larnaca​

Petrolina Apiron, from Larnaca, Cyprus, is a six-member team aged 18–19 from the American Academy Larnaca. Formed in October 2023, they placed second at Nationals and secured a World Finals spot in March 2025. Their name combines “Petrolina,” their title sponsor, and “Apiron,” Greek for infinity. Their car, MKM-25, reflects their journey and year.

​Development began in March, with challenges including military service and university transitions. Innovations include an IFTTT risk management diagram and strong sponsor partnerships. Petrolina Apiron is unique for being one of the few teams with a title sponsor, enabling access to advanced manufacturing and travel support. Their proudest moment was receiving confirmation of their World Finals qualification. Dream careers include engineering and entrepreneurship. Their favourite moment was the call from their mentor announcing their place at the World Finals, marking the culmination of months of uncertainty and hard work.

@petrolina.apiron

T70: S-Energy Country: Portugal​ SCHOOL:

S-Energy, from Vila Nova de Famalicão, Portugal, is a six-member team aged 15–17. Formed through a merger of two previous teams, they became National Champions in 2025. Their name derives from “synergy,” reflecting collaboration and unity. Their car, SEC-W25, is the latest in a series of refined designs.

Development began in June, with challenges in scheduling during summer holidays. Innovations include an AR-enhanced pit display and experimental aerodynamic concepts like converging-diverging nozzles. S-Energy is unique for bridging public and private schools and for its perseverance - rising from early eliminations to national victory. Their proudest moment was winning Nationals. Dream careers include motorsport engineering and team management. Their favourite moment was witnessing a thrilling knockout race at last year’s World Finals, inspiring them to bring the award back to Portugal.

@senergy.team​

T71: Starpoint Racing Country: Thailand SCHOOL: Bangkok Patana School​

Starpoint Racing, from Bangkok, Thailand, is a six-member team aged 16–18. Competing since 2023, they’ve won multiple national awards, including fastest car and best enterprise portfolio. Their name symbolises ambition and precision, with “Star” representing guidance and “Point” reflecting accuracy. Their car, Rama Rocket, honours Bangkok’s interconnected roads and cultural heritage.

​Development spanned a year, with challenges including school support, team absences, and military obligations. Innovations include branded merchandise, interactive pit games, and a signature Thai pattern. Starpoint Racing is unique for its independence and cross-functional expertise. Their proudest moment was winning the National Championship. Dream careers include biotechnology, diplomacy, racing, and creative direction. Their favourite moments include late-night calls and team bonding, which strengthened their unity and drive.

@starpointracing

T72: OMNIA VIRTUS Country: Mexico SCHOOL: Centro Escolar El Encino​

OMNIA VIRTUS, from Aguascalientes, Mexico, is a six-member team aged 18–19. Competing since 2022, they placed second nationally in 2025. Their name means “all virtues,” reflecting their holistic approach to teamwork and competition. Their car, MKM-25, represents their journey and year. Development began after Nationals, with challenges in fundraising, overcome through persistent sponsor outreach.

​Innovations include advanced engineering features and a strong team ethos. OMNIA VIRTUS is unique for its commitment to values and consistency. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals. Dream careers include mechanical engineering. Their favourite moment was hearing their name announced as runners-up, confirming their hard work and unity.

@omnia_virtus

T73: OWLA Country: Spain SCHOOL: IES José Luis López Aranguren​

OWLA, from Fuenlabrada, Spain, is a five-member team aged 13–18 from IES José Luis López Aranguren. Formed in March 2025, they won both the Madrid Regionals and Spanish Nationals in their debut season. Their name combines “OWL” and “HOLA,” symbolising wisdom and international greeting. Their car, VX-73, is named after their team number and features vortex-generating aerodynamics.

Development began post-Nationals, with challenges including broken cars and delayed wheel shipments. OWLA is unique for its rapid success, achieving national victory in under six months. Their proudest moment was winning the knockout competition and qualifying for the World Finals. Dream careers include aerospace engineering, acting, and mathematics. Their favourite moment was hearing their name announced as national champions. OWLA is the first public school team from Spain to reach the World Finals, and they aim to prove that talent and teamwork can overcome any barrier.

@owla_es

T74: Mercury Racing Country: Singapore SCHOOL: Tanglin Trust School​

Mercury Racing, from Tanglin Trust School in Singapore, is a five-member team aged 14–17. Formed in 2024, they placed third at Nationals and won Best Digital Media. Their name reflects speed, inspired by the Roman god and the fastest planet. Their car, Mercury Caloris MMXXV, is named after a planetary impact basin. Their mascot, Mark, is a green dinosaur plushie featured in branding.

​Development spanned five months, beginning with evaluation of their Nationals car. Sponsorship was a challenge, overcome by targeting SMEs. Innovations include a dual vane sidepod and fin-style rear pods for weight reduction. Mercury Racing is unique for its vintage aesthetic and multicultural team, representing Singapore and several other nations. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals. Dream careers include law, diplomacy, and engineering. Their favourite moment was seeing their car achieve the fastest time at Nationals, validating their design efforts.

@mercuryracingteam

T75: Zealim Racing Country: Hong Kong SCHOOL: HKFYG Lee Shau Kee College

Zealim Racing, from Tin Shui Wai, Hong Kong, is a six-member all-male team aged 16–17. Formed in 2024, they won their Regional Finals and Best Presentation Award. Their name blends “Zeal” and “Limit,” symbolising passion and overcoming obstacles. Their car, Hornet, reflects their bee-themed identity, with vibrant yellow and black branding.

​Development spanned four months, with challenges in balancing school and competition, resolved through structured timetables. Innovations include founding a STEM Racing club to ensure continuity and mentoring future students. Zealim Racing is unique for its all-rounded team, with members contributing across engineering and enterprise. Their proudest moment was establishing a legacy for future competitors. Dream careers include social media management and engineering. Their favourite moment was watching younger students engage with STEM Racing, knowing they had inspired the next generation.

@zealim_racing

T76: Yla Country: Saudi Arabia SCHOOL: STEM Racing Saudi​

Yla, from Khobar, Saudi Arabia, is a six-member team aged 16–19. Competing for three years, they qualified for the World Finals in 2025 after placing fourth nationally. Their name stands for “Youth Living in Acceleration,” and their car, Accelion, reflects speed and vision. Their mascot, Khalid, symbolises eternal ambition.

​Development began after Nationals, with challenges including their team leader relocating abroad, solved through remote collaboration and leadership restructuring. Innovations include the YLA Keyboard for productivity and a STEM therapy tool for children with disabilities. Yla is unique for its professional approach and social impact. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals after years of near misses. Dream careers include team principal and engineering. Their favourite moment was hearing their name announced for the World Finals, a symbol of persistence and growth.

@yla.accelerate

T77: Velkoi Racing Country: Greece SCHOOL: American Farm School, The Moraitis School, 2nd Model Highschool of Athens​ ​

Velkoi Racing, from Athens, Greece, is a six-member team aged 16–19. Formed through collaboration between three schools, they’ve competed for a decade and hold the Greek national record for fastest car. Their name combines “velocity” and “koinonia” (community), reflecting speed and unity. Their car, simply named Car A and Car B, was developed from May onwards.​Their mascot, SPEEDY, is a miniature F1 racer featured in their branding. Challenges included remote collaboration and scheduling, solved through structured planning and task sharing. Innovations include recycled plastic merchandise and advanced modelling techniques. Velkoi is unique for its diversity and cross-city teamwork. Their proudest moment was winning Nationals and meeting in person for the first time. Dream careers include engineering and medicine. Their favourite moment was the pit display exhibition, where they refined their identity through interaction with other teams.

@Velkoiracing

T78: Synergy Country: Brazil SCHOOL: FourC Bilingual Academy​

Synergy, from Bauru, Brazil, is a six-member team aged 14–18. Formed in 2024, they placed second nationally and won awards for engineering, fastest car, and social impact. Their name reflects collaborative strength, with the tagline “Driven Together.” Their car, SYWF-25, represents their journey to the World Finals. Development began in June, with challenges including axle insert failures, solved through creative repair techniques.

Innovations include a new wheel design and STEM outreach kits. Synergy is unique for its blend of technical excellence and community engagement. Their proudest moment was mentoring younger students and expanding STEM Racing in Brazil. Dream careers include engineering, pharmaceuticals, and social entrepreneurship. Their favourite moment was seeing their car break the 1.2-second barrier, a milestone of precision and teamwork.

@synergybr_

T79: Team SW1FT Country: United States of America SCHOOL: Arnold O. Beckman High School​

STEM Racing. Founded in 2024, they placed 2nd at the North America Regional Finals and 3rd at the USA & Canada National Finals, earning Best Verbal Presentation and Best Newcomer awards. Their name honours Blue Moon, a pet bird of their founder, symbolising freedom and agility. Their car, simply called SW1FT, reflects speed and endurance, while their mascot, also Blue Moon, embodies boldness and resilience.

Development began in June 2025, with challenges including CNC adaptation and team member changes, overcome through custom fixtures and buffer planning. Innovations include a wind tunnel, Python-based reaction training, and a sponsorship ecosystem. What makes Team SW1FT unique is their persistence and ability to learn everything from scratch. Their proudest moment was hearing their name announced as 3rd place at Nationals, validating their hard work and inspiring their World Finals journey.

@swift.f1is

T80: IMPETUS RACERS Country: India

Impetus Racers, from India, is a four-member team aged 13–16 from their school in India. Formed in 2022, they quickly rose through the ranks - placing in the top 25 at Nationals in their debut season, then achieving a top 10 finish the following year. In 2025, they secured 3rd place at Nationals and earned a spot at the World Finals. Their name, “Impetus,” reflects energy and momentum - both physical and motivational.

​Development of their World Finals car began in August, using a prototype-based approach and iterative testing. Despite setbacks, including a key team member stepping down, they adapted swiftly and maintained progress. Innovations include a flexible rear wing, modular components, and the Impetus Initiative, an NGO-driven outreach programme. Impetus Racers stand out for their blend of technical excellence, sustainability, and community impact. Their proudest moment was placing 3rd at Nationals and breaking the reaction time record with 0.013s.

@impetusracers

T81: Team Rabbits Country: Italy SCHOOL: Itis Silvio De Pretto​

Team Rabbits, from Schio, Italy, is a six-member team aged 19–20 from Itis Silvio De Pretto. Their name was given by a teacher after they skipped a test to focus on competition prep - earning the nickname “Rabbits” for their speed and determination. Their car, RT04, follows a naming system based on competition stages. Their mascot, Arturo the rabbit, wears their historic team T-shirt and joins them at sponsor meetings.

​Their proudest moment was receiving praise from judges at Nationals, who called their documentation “perfect” and recognised their unique personality. Team Rabbits is known for their unconventional name, strong identity, and ability to find joy in simple things. While they’re highly determined and competitive, they also value fun and creativity. Their journey reflects a balance of hard work and light-hearted spirit, making them stand out in the STEM Racing community.

@teamrabbits_

T82: Team Phoenix Country: Japan SCHOOL: Fukui Senior High School​

Team Phoenix, from Fukui City, Japan, is a four-member all-male team aged 16–18 from Fukui Senior High School. Their name honours the phoenix, the symbol of their hometown, with wings spread wide to represent ambition. Their car, FP-25, stands for Fukui Phoenix 2025. Though they don’t have a mascot, their identity is rooted in simplicity and clarity.

​Their proudest experience was participating in the Pit Lane Walk, a moment that connected them with the global STEM Racing community. Team Phoenix is unique for its clean, data-driven design approach, making their development process accessible and engaging to other teams. Their work reflects a thoughtful balance between technical rigour and visual simplicity, aiming to inspire interest and collaboration. With a strong sense of local pride and a clear vision, Team Phoenix brings a quiet strength to the World Finals.

@stemracing_phoenix

T83: Aeris Country: France SCHOOL: Lycée Jean Mermoz​

Aeris, from France, is an eight-member team formed in September 2024 by a group of friends passionate about engineering. They won the French National Finals, earning awards for the fastest car and Women & Sport, securing their place at the 2025 World Finals in Singapore. Their name, Aeris, comes from the Latin word aer, meaning “air,” symbolising fluidity and aerodynamic excellence.

Their car, APEX-evo, blends “Apex” for racing precision and “Evo” for evolution, reflecting their commitment to innovation. Development spanned five months, guided by a structured R&D and production timeline. A major challenge was a legal issue affecting their association’s banking, which they overcame with parental support. Innovations include a refined diffuser, halo airflow optimisation, and sustainable PLA aero parts. Aeris is unique for its diversity, adaptability, and strong team bond. Their proudest achievement is representing France at the World Finals and growing both technically and personally.

@aeris.racing

T84: Vega Racing by ASAM Country: Scotland SCHOOL: Linlithgow Academy​

Vega Racing by ASAM, from Linlithgow, Scotland, is a four-member all-male team aged 17–18 from Linlithgow Academy. Their name is inspired by the star Vega, a key figure in scientific discovery. Their car, Lyra, is named after the constellation in which Vega resides. Development began in late March, building on skills honed since joining the Pro Class in 2023.

​A major challenge was being unable to attend the 2024 World Finals, which they overcame with perseverance and renewed focus. Vega Racing is unique for its long-standing team unity, with all original members still competing together after nearly four years. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals a second time. Their favourite experience was touring the F1 paddock at the 2024 British Grand Prix, a moment that deepened their passion for motorsport and STEM.

@vegaracing_f1is

T85: Ventaurus Competative Country: United Kingdom SCHOOL: Harrow School​

Ventaurus Competitive, from Harrow, England, is a six-member all-male team aged 16 from Harrow School. Their name combines “Venti” (wind spirit) and “Taurus” (bull), symbolising speed, strength, and determination. Their car, Bullseye MK2, reflects their mascot and logo, representing precision and development. Over four months, they faced challenges including warped SLS prints and shattered components, which they overcame through redesign and testing.

​Innovations include graphite-coated wheels and a custom formula for optimising wheel shell thickness. Their mascot, Tauro the bull, features prominently in branding and merchandise. Ventaurus Competitive is unique for its commitment to sustainability, operating as a carbon-negative team and collaborating with NGOs. Their proudest moment was winning Best Pit Display at Nationals, a recognition of their identity and creativity. Their favourite experience was seeing their efforts celebrated and inspiring others to pursue a greener future through STEM Racing.

@ventaurus.gb

    • CONTACT

THE CHALLENGE

The STEM Racing challenge in USA is an annual STEM competition that challenges students from across the US and Canada at the regional and national level. Designed for teachers, informed by engineers, and endorsed by Formula 1, this program sets students on the fast track to STEM success; and provides a lot of fun on the way there. The competition features several ‘project elements,’ detailed below and two classes of competition. It may look like a lot for a team of three to six students, but many talented students rise to the challenge each year and produce incredible products! Are you ready for the challenge?

Visit www.stemracing.us for more information on how to participate in the USA

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

Contact USA
☰

      • PARTNERSHIPS

      • FRANCHISING
    • CONTACT

HOW DOES IT WORK

Creating their own version of an F1 team, students work together in groups of 3-6. Assigning roles and responsibilities, each individual takes ownership of a specific area, such as designing the car, manufacturing it, testing it or branding it. They then work together to create various project elements, such as a Design & Engineering portfolio, and delivery of a verbal presentation.

THE CLASSES

Developed to be accessible to all students, and to encourage and progress learning, the STEM Racing competition is segmented into different categories which are tailored to age and experience. These are Primary Class, Entry Class, Development Class, and Professional Class. Each class is built around the fundamentals of the competition - design, analyse, make, test, race, and project management - with added layers of complexity and additional requirements introduced as teams progress through the programme.

THE EVENTS

Once a team has developed their project work, they are able to compete in STEM Racing events, where they race against other teams, as well as presenting to a team of judges, comprised of industry professionals (and sometimes members of F1 teams!). These events begin at regional level, progress to national, and, for the very best, culminate in competing against other countries in the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals.

THE TIME

STEM Racing can be approached in a way that works for you. Whether it is a regular extracurricular activity or a project that complements an existing class, you can create a timeline that fits your needs. We recommend a minimum of an hour a week across the first and second half terms to ensure teams have enough time to complete each part of the project and build their car prior to a regional final.

© COPYRIGHT ALL RIGHTS RESERVED
