Their name symbolises unity, with the motto “The unity that drives us.” Their car, Gear SR-1, marks their debut on the global stage. Development began in March, with challenges including a failed paint job, resolved by remanufacturing the car in one week.

T40: Apex Racing Country: India

APEX Racing, from India, is a six-member all-male team aged 14–17. Established in 2020, they’ve consistently placed in the top 10 nationally and won the Fastest Car Award in 2024. Their name refers to the apex of a racing corner, symbolising precision and peak performance. Development of their car took 3–4 months, with major setbacks including the departure of their team manager and mentor.

​They rebuilt their car and deliverables from scratch, regaining momentum through full-day meetings and strategic social media growth. Innovations include a PET fusion machine for recycling plastic into filament, AI generative design, and MDF mini car kits. APEX Racing is unique for its resilience and ability to overcome critical challenges. Their proudest moment was completing all deliverables under pressure. Dream careers include F1 car design, mechanical engineering, and business. Their favourite moment was winning Nationals and proving their strength as a team.

T45: Lunar Country: Australia SCHOOL: Brighton Grammar School​

Lunar, from Brighton Grammar School in Australia, is a five-member team aged 17. Competing since 2022, they’ve won two National Finals and placed third at the 2024 World Finals. Their name symbolises engineering ambition, inspired by astronauts and Indigenous Australian traditions. Their car, Japarra, means “moon and stars” in Tiwi, honouring First Nations heritage. Their mascot, Lunar Larry, is a recycled costume referencing Buzz Lightyear. Development began in June, with CNC breakdowns resolved by travelling across Melbourne to complete manufacturing. Innovations include aluminium wheels produced via laser powder bed fusion in collaboration with Monash University. Lunar is unique for its cultural representation and technical excellence. Their proudest moment was placing third at the World Finals and attending the Qatar Grand Prix. Dream careers include engineering and architecture. T47: MACH10 Country: Singapore SCHOOL: Global Indian International School​

MACH10, from Singapore’s Global Indian International School, is a five-member team aged 16–18. Founded in 2024, they placed second at Nationals and won multiple awards. Their name references the speed of sound and the film Top Gun: Maverick. Their car, Darkstar, is named after the film’s hypersonic jet. Their mascot, Velocitron, is a futuristic robot inspired by Transformers and their car’s aerodynamic profile.

​Development began in January, pivoting from Nationals to World Finals preparation. Challenges included exam clashes and manufacturing delays, solved through task division and scheduling. Innovations include a digital racing game and precision machining tools. MACH10 is unique for being their school’s first team to reach the World Finals, with a strong identity and resilience. @t3ammach

T48: Koru Racing Country: New Zealand SCHOOL: Saint Kentigern College​

Koru Racing, from Auckland, New Zealand, is a three-member team aged 17–18. Founded in April 2024, they became national champions and won the Fastest Car Award at the Australian Nationals. Their name, “Koru,” refers to the spiral of a silver fern, symbolising growth and strength in Māori culture. Their car, KR4, is the fourth generation of their design.

Development began in July, with daily testing and refinement. Sponsorship was a major challenge, overcome through persistent outreach. Innovations include vortex generators, nozzle-style rear wings, and a mathematical car motion model. Koru Racing is unique as New Zealand’s first team to reach the World Finals, proudly representing Kiwi ingenuity. Their proudest moment was winning the Fastest Car Award in Australia. Dream careers include software engineering and entrepreneurship. Their favourite moment was hosting their school’s STEM Racing competition, inspiring future teams to follow in their footsteps.

@koruracing.nz

T49: Nexus Racing Team Country: Greece SCHOOL: Anatolia College, 1st General Lyceum Xilokastro​

Nexus Racing, from Thessaloniki, Greece, is a five-member team aged 15–18. Formed from two experienced teams, they qualified for the World Finals after months of collaboration. Their name, “Nexus,” means connection, symbolising unity across distance and difference. Their car, Paralus, is named after an ancient Athenian ship, representing honour and teamwork.

Development began in summer, with challenges including time constraints and high costs. Innovations include aerodynamic wing shapes, lightweight 3D-printed parts, and unique branding. Nexus Racing is unique for its strong teamwork and creative problem-solving. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals and securing sponsorships through community engagement. Dream careers include engineering and design. Their favourite moment was competing at Nationals and seeing their efforts come to life, proving that collaboration and resilience can overcome any challenge.

@nexusracing2025

T50: Molding Performance Country: Portugal

Molding Performance, from Leiria, Portugal, is a three-member team aged 17–19. Competing since 2022, they’ve won three consecutive regional championships and placed on the national podium twice. Their name reflects the local mould industry and their engineering ethos. Their car, MP-25 RCC, is named after a supportive professor.

Development lasted four months, with challenges in documentation, resolved through teacher support. Innovations include a proposed AI team and a strong regional identity showcased in their pit display. Molding Performance is unique for its resilience and pride in representing their community. Their proudest moment was winning second place nationally. Dream careers include IT, automotive sales, and software development. Their favourite moment was standing on the national podium, a symbol of their growth and determination.

@molding_performance

T51: LYNX Country: Spain SCHOOL: American School of Barcelona​

LYNX, from Barcelona, Spain, is a five-member team aged 17–18. Formed in October 2024, they placed third at Nationals and won Best Engineered Car and R&D. Their name honours the Iberian lynx, their school mascot and a symbol of Spanish wildlife. Their car, LR02, continues a naming system based on development stages. Their mascot is a lynx, reinforcing their identity.​Development began in June, with challenges in part tolerances, resolved through supplier collaboration. Innovations include a CO₂ test rig and volumetric lattice structures. LYNX is unique for its strong values and sponsor relationships. Their proudest moment was matching the fastest time from the previous World Finals. Dream careers include engineering, law, and design. Their favourite moment was assembling their car and seeing their hard work come together.

@lynxracing.spain

T52: LAYANG Country: Malaysia SCHOOL: SMK Bandar Putra

Layang, from Kulai, Malaysia, is a four-member all-female team aged 15–16. Formed in 2023, they became National Champions in 2025, winning Best Enterprise. Their name means “to fly” in Malay, inspired by traditional wau kites. Their car, Langit, symbolises reaching new heights. Their mascot, Skyle, is a peacock-kite hybrid designed to connect with younger audiences. ​Development spanned six months. Challenges included gender bias, which they overcame by proving their capability and gaining media support. Innovations include a screw-fastened double bearing wheel system and SkyleSync, a verbal presentation timing watch. Layang is unique for its energy, multicultural makeup, and advocacy for inclusivity, including support for visually impaired students. Their proudest moment was winning Nationals and bonding through shared cultural experiences. Dream careers include architecture, engineering, and marine technology. Their favourite moment was practising their presentation roadside - an unforgettable lesson in time management.

@FlyWithLayang

T53: RACEDAM RACING TEAM Country: Mexico SCHOOL: Colegio San Ángel​

RACEDAM, from Puebla, Mexico, is a four-member all-female team aged 17–18 from Colegio San Ángel. Founded in 2023, they’ve earned awards for digital media, innovation, and social responsibility. Their name is an acronym of their core values: Respect, Love, Creativity, Entrepreneurship, Dynamism, Friendship, and Goals. Their car, R∆ Evo, symbolises change and evolution. Their mascot, Raven Raya, is a white tiger representing strength and resilience, with plushies sold to fundraise.

​Development spanned four months, with challenges including late confirmation of World Finals qualification and financial constraints. Innovations include recycled PET uniforms and a spiral wheel suspension system. RACEDAM is unique for its social impact, working with cancer and food bank charities, and promoting breast cancer awareness. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals. Dream careers include cinema, engineering, and entertainment management. Their favourite moment was racing together and feeling the adrenaline of competition.

@racedam_rt

Mercury VN, from Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, is a six-member team aged 17–18. Formed through a shared passion for STEM, they won the Vietnam Nationals and qualified for the World Finals. Their name honours Mercury, the Roman god of commerce and communication. Their car, Stratos, is named after the stratosphere and pays tribute to their teacher.

​Development spanned eight months, with challenges in structural failure, resolved through design review and collaboration. Innovations include detachable wings, cantilever axles, and honeycomb-spoke wheels. Mercury VN is unique for its pursuit of excellence and cultural symbolism. T55: SPYKAR Country: China

SPYKAR, from Shanghai, China, is a six-member team aged 16–17. With a legacy dating back to 2017, they’ve consistently ranked highly in national and international competitions. Their name stands for Science, Passion, Youth, Knowledge, Action, and Revolution. Their car, unnamed, was developed through multiple iterations, with final assembly completed in September. Their mascots, SPY and KAR, are teddy bears representing logic and warmth. A major challenge was losing engineering drawings to file corruption, which they overcame through risk management planning.

Innovations include aerodynamic sidepods inspired by Ferrari’s F1-75 and a wing-style rearpod. SPYKAR is unique for its tailored sponsorship ROI strategies and creative outreach. Their proudest moment was winning the National Championship and qualifying for the World Finals. Dream careers include engineering, architecture, and aviation. Their favourite moment was hearing their name announced as champions, fulfilling a long-held ambition.

@25spykar​

LUMINOX, from Madrid, Spain, is a four-member team aged 17. Formed in October 2025, they placed second at Nationals and won awards for fastest car and team identity. Their name combines “lumi” (light) and “nox” (darkness), symbolising unity through contrast. Their car, Freya, is named after the Norse goddess of love and beauty.

Development spanned two months, with challenges in sponsorship, solved through creative outreach. Innovations include a music-themed pit display and engaging activities to make STEM Racing more accessible. LUMINOX is unique for highlighting the creative side of STEM and embracing diversity. Their proudest moment was launching their car at Nationals and exceeding expectations. Dream careers include F1 aerodynamics, marketing, and data analysis. Parabolica, from Cardiff, Wales, is a three-member all-female team aged 16. Formed in 2022, they’ve competed for three seasons, winning awards for engineering, portfolios, and becoming Welsh Champions. Their name is inspired by the final curve at Monza’s Temple of Speed. Their car, PB4, follows a naming convention similar to real F1 cars.

​Development began in June, immediately after GCSEs. A major challenge was a wheel detaching during Regionals, which they overcame with a spare car. Their pit display is a standout feature - an escape room-style experience where visitors solve clues to unlock the car. Parabolica is unique for its mission to inspire girls in STEM and motorsport. Their proudest moment was winning the Portfolio Award at Nationals. Dream careers include law, aeronautics, and working in Formula 1. Their favourite moment was being told “See you in Singapore!” after winning the Welsh title, confirming their place at the World Finals.

Their name reflects the fusion of skills and experiences. Their car, FR-61, was developed over 2.5 months. Fusion Racing is unique for its sustainability focus and being the only public school representing Australia. Their proudest moment was winning Nationals. T79: Team SW1FT Country: United States of America SCHOOL: Arnold O. Beckman High School​

STEM Racing. Founded in 2024, they placed 2nd at the North America Regional Finals and 3rd at the USA & Canada National Finals, earning Best Verbal Presentation and Best Newcomer awards. Their name honours Blue Moon, a pet bird of their founder, symbolising freedom and agility. Their car, simply called SW1FT, reflects speed and endurance, while their mascot, also Blue Moon, embodies boldness and resilience.

Development began in June 2025, with challenges including CNC adaptation and team member changes, overcome through custom fixtures and buffer planning. Innovations include a wind tunnel, Python-based reaction training, and a sponsorship ecosystem. What makes Team SW1FT unique is their persistence and ability to learn everything from scratch. T80: IMPETUS RACERS Country: India

Impetus Racers, from India, is a four-member team aged 13–16 from their school in India. Formed in 2022, they quickly rose through the ranks - placing in the top 25 at Nationals in their debut season, then achieving a top 10 finish the following year. In 2025, they secured 3rd place at Nationals and earned a spot at the World Finals. Their name, “Impetus,” reflects energy and momentum - both physical and motivational.

​Development of their World Finals car began in August, using a prototype-based approach and iterative testing. Despite setbacks, including a key team member stepping down, they adapted swiftly and maintained progress. Innovations include a flexible rear wing, modular components, and the Impetus Initiative, an NGO-driven outreach programme. Impetus Racers stand out for their blend of technical excellence, sustainability, and community impact. Their proudest moment was placing 3rd at Nationals and breaking the reaction time record with 0.013s.

@impetusracers

T81: Team Rabbits Country: Italy SCHOOL: Itis Silvio De Pretto​

Team Rabbits, from Schio, Italy, is a six-member team aged 19–20 from Itis Silvio De Pretto. Their name was given by a teacher after they skipped a test to focus on competition prep - earning the nickname “Rabbits” for their speed and determination. Their car, RT04, follows a naming system based on competition stages. Their mascot, Arturo the rabbit, wears their historic team T-shirt and joins them at sponsor meetings.

​Their proudest moment was receiving praise from judges at Nationals, who called their documentation “perfect” and recognised their unique personality. Team Rabbits is known for their unconventional name, strong identity, and ability to find joy in simple things. While they’re highly determined and competitive, they also value fun and creativity. Their journey reflects a balance of hard work and light-hearted spirit, making them stand out in the STEM Racing community.

@teamrabbits_

T82: Team Phoenix Country: Japan SCHOOL: Fukui Senior High School​

Team Phoenix, from Fukui City, Japan, is a four-member all-male team aged 16–18 from Fukui Senior High School. Their name honours the phoenix, the symbol of their hometown, with wings spread wide to represent ambition. Their car, FP-25, stands for Fukui Phoenix 2025. Though they don’t have a mascot, their identity is rooted in simplicity and clarity.

​Their proudest experience was participating in the Pit Lane Walk, a moment that connected them with the global STEM Racing community. Team Phoenix is unique for its clean, data-driven design approach, making their development process accessible and engaging to other teams. Their work reflects a thoughtful balance between technical rigour and visual simplicity, aiming to inspire interest and collaboration. With a strong sense of local pride and a clear vision, Team Phoenix brings a quiet strength to the World Finals.

@stemracing_phoenix

T83: Aeris Country: France SCHOOL: Lycée Jean Mermoz​

Aeris, from France, is an eight-member team formed in September 2024 by a group of friends passionate about engineering. They won the French National Finals, earning awards for the fastest car and Women & Sport, securing their place at the 2025 World Finals in Singapore. Their name, Aeris, comes from the Latin word aer, meaning “air,” symbolising fluidity and aerodynamic excellence.

Their car, APEX-evo, blends “Apex” for racing precision and “Evo” for evolution, reflecting their commitment to innovation. Development spanned five months, guided by a structured R&D and production timeline. A major challenge was a legal issue affecting their association’s banking, which they overcame with parental support. Innovations include a refined diffuser, halo airflow optimisation, and sustainable PLA aero parts. Aeris is unique for its diversity, adaptability, and strong team bond. Their proudest achievement is representing France at the World Finals and growing both technically and personally.

@aeris.racing

T84: Vega Racing by ASAM Country: Scotland SCHOOL: Linlithgow Academy​

Vega Racing by ASAM, from Linlithgow, Scotland, is a four-member all-male team aged 17–18 from Linlithgow Academy. Their name is inspired by the star Vega, a key figure in scientific discovery. Their car, Lyra, is named after the constellation in which Vega resides. Development began in late March, building on skills honed since joining the Pro Class in 2023.

​A major challenge was being unable to attend the 2024 World Finals, which they overcame with perseverance and renewed focus. Vega Racing is unique for its long-standing team unity, with all original members still competing together after nearly four years. Their proudest moment was qualifying for the World Finals a second time. Their favourite experience was touring the F1 paddock at the 2024 British Grand Prix, a moment that deepened their passion for motorsport and STEM.

@vegaracing_f1is

T85: Ventaurus Competative Country: United Kingdom SCHOOL: Harrow School​

Ventaurus Competitive, from Harrow, England, is a six-member all-male team aged 16 from Harrow School. Their name combines “Venti” (wind spirit) and “Taurus” (bull), symbolising speed, strength, and determination. Their car, Bullseye MK2, reflects their mascot and logo, representing precision and development. Over four months, they faced challenges including warped SLS prints and shattered components, which they overcame through redesign and testing.

​Innovations include graphite-coated wheels and a custom formula for optimising wheel shell thickness. Their mascot, Tauro the bull, features prominently in branding and merchandise. Ventaurus Competitive is unique for its commitment to sustainability, operating as a carbon-negative team and collaborating with NGOs. Their proudest moment was winning Best Pit Display at Nationals, a recognition of their identity and creativity. Their favourite experience was seeing their efforts celebrated and inspiring others to pursue a greener future through STEM Racing.

@ventaurus.gb

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

THE CHALLENGE

The STEM Racing challenge in USA is an annual STEM competition that challenges students from across the US and Canada at the regional and national level. Designed for teachers, informed by engineers, and endorsed by Formula 1, this program sets students on the fast track to STEM success; and provides a lot of fun on the way there. The competition features several ‘project elements,’ detailed below and two classes of competition. It may look like a lot for a team of three to six students, but many talented students rise to the challenge each year and produce incredible products! Are you ready for the challenge?

Visit www.stemracing.us for more information on how to participate in the USA

© COPYRIGHTS ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

Contact USA

    • CONTACT

HOW DOES IT WORK

Creating their own version of an F1 team, students work together in groups of 3-6. Assigning roles and responsibilities, each individual takes ownership of a specific area, such as designing the car, manufacturing it, testing it or branding it. They then work together to create various project elements, such as a Design & Engineering portfolio, and delivery of a verbal presentation.

THE CLASSES

Developed to be accessible to all students, and to encourage and progress learning, the STEM Racing competition is segmented into different categories which are tailored to age and experience. These are Primary Class, Entry Class, Development Class, and Professional Class. Each class is built around the fundamentals of the competition - design, analyse, make, test, race, and project management - with added layers of complexity and additional requirements introduced as teams progress through the programme.

THE EVENTS

Once a team has developed their project work, they are able to compete in STEM Racing events, where they race against other teams, as well as presenting to a team of judges, comprised of industry professionals (and sometimes members of F1 teams!). These events begin at regional level, progress to national, and, for the very best, culminate in competing against other countries in the Aramco STEM Racing World Finals.

THE TIME

STEM Racing can be approached in a way that works for you. Whether it is a regular extracurricular activity or a project that complements an existing class, you can create a timeline that fits your needs. We recommend a minimum of an hour a week across the first and second half terms to ensure teams have enough time to complete each part of the project and build their car prior to a regional final.

© COPYRIGHT ALL RIGHTS RESERVED
